[{'created': '2014-07-29 12:41:17.000000000', 'message': "upgrade.sh: add ability to run certain upgraders

Since our upgrade tarball has both upgraders for master node and
openstack upgrader, we should provide a way to run only certain
ones. For instance, it's a very useful workflow when we can run
just openstack upgrader to test openstack patching.

Upgraders to run could be specified throughout special env variable,
which is widespread way to parametrize some process in Unix world:

Usage example:

    $ UPGRADERS='openstack' ./upgrade.sh

The command above will run just openstack upgrader, no matter which
upgraders was hardcoded in upgrade.sh.

Change-Id: I601ad84eba6403dc6a1885b6ea452056a9b667af
Blueprint: upgrade-to-5-1
"}]
commit_message:
upgrade.sh: add ability to run certain upgraders

Since our upgrade tarball has both upgraders for master node and
openstack upgrader, we should provide a way to run only certain
ones. For instance, it's a very useful workflow when we can run
just openstack upgrader to test openstack patching.

Upgraders to run could be specified throughout special env variable,
which is widespread way to parametrize some process in Unix world:

Usage example:

    $ UPGRADERS='openstack' ./upgrade.sh

The command above will run just openstack upgrader, no matter which
upgraders was hardcoded in upgrade.sh.

Change-Id: I601ad84eba6403dc6a1885b6ea452056a9b667af
Blueprint: upgrade-to-5-1

commit_message:
Add log output about the details of libvirt events

This patch enables nova-compute to output the details of
libvirt events to the log when nova-compute handles libvirt events.

Change-Id: I6ecc71c840bd0a0bd753f0222ca094143b55ed02
Closes-bug: #1311082

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-28 03:14:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add workbook_name and last_execution to "pipeline show"

This makes it easy for the user to then run a mistral command to get the task output

 mistral execution-get <workbook_name> <execution>
 mistral task-list <workbook_name> <execution>

Change-Id: I09c7b18cd316a088c17cd2b37ec65c223e9d2e83
'}]
commit_message:
Add workbook_name and last_execution to "pipeline show"

This makes it easy for the user to then run a mistral command to get the task output

 mistral execution-get <workbook_name> <execution>
 mistral task-list <workbook_name> <execution>

Change-Id: I09c7b18cd316a088c17cd2b37ec65c223e9d2e83

commit_message:
Add testcase for multiple discovery-driven sources

This test was intended to reproduce the reported issue around
resources discovered for one pollster bleeding into the resource
list passed to an unrelated pollster with the same interval.

However the observed behaviour seems correct.

Related-bug: #1335986
Change-Id: Ifb608246ad2ee2d858b4268ae2e8dc6faaff025c

commit_message:
libvirt: remove 3 unused vif.py methods

In the following commit:

  commit 842b2abfe76dede55b3b61ebaad5a90c356c5ace
  Author: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
  Date:   Mon Nov 25 14:00:25 2013 +0000

    Increase min required libvirt to 0.9.11

support for setting up OVS outside of libvirt was dropped,
but 3 of the helper methods were mistakenly not deleted.

Related-bug: #1254727
Change-Id: I53de8703a64d1214ec81b9698e376737a92cb53a

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-29 10:09:21.000000000', 'message': 'functions.guest: add iniset_sudo, a root wrapper around iniset

This changeset introduces iniset_sudo, a root wrapper around the
devstack function, iniset.

The wrapper function makes it easier to have comments explaining
lines changes to configuration files.

Instead of sourcing the devstack library in the root environment as
well, iniset_sudo works on a temporary copy of the configuration file
and uses root privileges only to copy the result back into place. It
would have to be modified before it could edit files that the script
user has no permission to read.

The changeset illustrates the use of the function with a patched
apt_install_mysql.sh

Change-Id: I416c0d14280e774a939d7bebaf7d45c3a488e763
'}]
commit_message:
functions.guest: add iniset_sudo, a root wrapper around iniset

This changeset introduces iniset_sudo, a root wrapper around the
devstack function, iniset.

The wrapper function makes it easier to have comments explaining
lines changes to configuration files.

Instead of sourcing the devstack library in the root environment as
well, iniset_sudo works on a temporary copy of the configuration file
and uses root privileges only to copy the result back into place. It
would have to be modified before it could edit files that the script
user has no permission to read.

The changeset illustrates the use of the function with a patched
apt_install_mysql.sh

Change-Id: I416c0d14280e774a939d7bebaf7d45c3a488e763

Hi! Code lgtm. I'm thinking about testing here - we have no way of validation these complex command lines, except for copying them into our shells. Could you invent some way of testing them?

At least, it would be great to test that reasonable command line is passed to SSH, so that reviewers can copy-paste it to the shell :) That still seems to be unverifiable though... Another suggestion would be to move as much as possible (e.g. parsing XML's to testeable Python code), not sure how doable it is."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-05-05 09:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

commit_message:
SSH virsh to use the new ManagementInterface

Add the new ManagementInterface to the SSH driver. Only the 'virsh'
virt_type is supported for now.

Implements: blueprint new-management-interface
Change-Id: I36b704e4d9daa902393b3f79405bf288d9ee0872

subject: Allow controlled shutdown of GuestOS for operations which power off the VM
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1779, 'name': 'Daniel Berrange', 'email': 'berrange@redhat.com', 'username': 'berrange'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'yunhong-jiang'}, {'_account_id': 4690, 'name': 'melanie witt', 'display_name': 'melwitt', 'email': 'melwittt@gmail.com', 'username': 'melwitt'}, {'_account_id': 4912, 'name': 'Michael H Wilson', 'email': 'geekinutah@gmail.com', 'username': 'geekinutah'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 6062, 'name': 'jichenjc', 'email': 'jichenjc@cn.ibm.com', 'username': 'jichenjc'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 8276, 'name': 'kiwik', 'email': 'chenrui.momo@gmail.com', 'username': 'kiwik'}, {'_account_id': 8328, 'name': 'Mike Spreitzer', 'email': 'mspreitz@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'mspreitz'}, {'_account_id': 8688, messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-22 17:18:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 136, 'date': '2014-04-22 17:39:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Great functionality that would be a help for us. A few clarifications on the specs (but a +1 from me for the aims)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-04-22 19:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/50/89650/1/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/8681534 : SUCCESS in 1m 01s
- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/50/89650/1/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/6314100/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 34s
'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2014-04-22 19:57:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(14 inline comments)

The list of APIs to change seems a bit inconsistent.

There is also something I don't like about the mix of config options and API changes and client changes to those APIs with the --clean-shutdown parameter.

Part of me thinks make the default the existing behavior (clean_shutdown=False) and then the user can control how they want to use the APIs with the --clean-shutdown parameter.

Alternatively, you could make the default clean_shutdown=False for Juno and then change the default to be True for K, I saw you had this idea with respect to vif_plugging_is_fatal for Icehouse in the mailing list.

It just seems awkward to have a configuration where I can say clean_shutdown=False and then the API user can override that."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2014-04-22 23:22:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (11 inline comments)

I'm always wary about pushing policy deep into the stack.

Why can't this be controlled by the user?

Before I get into a possible alternative, why would a user want a clean shutdown before a delete? What are they expecting will happen to their data after the instance has been deleted?

If there is a reason why a clean shutdown is required, would requesting a clean power off before a delete be sufficient?

Also, can the interval and retries be pushed up to the user control?

For instance, if the client wants a clean shutdown, they could request a clean power off (adds one flag to the API). Retries (requesting another clean power off) and timeouts (moving on to hard power off or other operation) could be handled by the client as well.

It looks like we may only need one change, which is the option to do a clean power off. Everything else could potentially be handled by the client and in whatever policy they want (however simple or complicated they want it to be)."}, {'account_id': 136, 'date': '2014-04-23 06:54:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If my VM has volumes attached (such as through cinder), I'd want a clean shutdown so that volume could be used elsewhere.

Currently, AFAIK, there is no mechanism for the user to specify the clean shutdown time."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-04-23 09:19:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks all for the feedback - I'll address the in-line comments directly in the next pass but wanted to respond to more general points first:


Matt: There is also something I don't like about the mix of config options and API changes and client changes to those APIs with the --clean_shutdown parameter.

The config options define the timing of how to shutdown the VM (nova.conf provides generic defaults, images can provide different values tailored to the specific OS - for example Windows may need longer than most Linux guests)
The clean_shutdown parameter provides user control over whether to do a clean shutdown or not.  So I think they are complementary (think reboot_type at the API level and conf.wait_soft_reboot_seconds


Matt: Alternatively, you could make the default clean_shutdown=False for Juno and then change the default to be True for K, I saw you had this idea with respect to vif_plugging_is_fatal for Icehouse in the mailing list.

We could make the default for all cases to not do a clean_shutdown, but then we wouldn't get any control over this until the full BP is implemented, and I know from previous attempts on this problem that I need to do this in a number of steps working up from the virt layer (just adding a parameter through the RPC layer touches way more files that you'd expect given the interaction with cells).  IMO not doing a clean shutdown outside of delete is a bug since it risks breaking the Guest, so I'd like to get that case handled properly by default as soon as possible.   There is WIP code for this already here:  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/68942/


Johannes: I'm always wary about pushing policy deep into the stack. Why can't this be controlled by the user?

This is probably covered by my answer above, but it will be controllable by the user, however I think all they want/need to be able to do is express a binary option.  The config values are there to control how that is carried out.    For every user option there needs to be a default policy in the code, and the current default for operations other than delete seems wrong to me.


Johannes: Before I get into a possible alternative, why would a user want a clean shutdown before a delete? What are they expecting will happen to their data after the instance has been deleted?

If they are booting from a volume the data is very much still around.


Johannes: If there is a reason why a clean shutdown is required, would requesting a clean power off before a delete be sufficient?

I think this might be a good simplification - leave delete as it is and add the controlled shutdown just to stop, so users who want a controlled shutdown before a delete would need to perform a stop operation first.  The only minor issues I see with that are a) Stop isn't part of the core API, so its possible that its not implemented on all systems, and b) it may not be obvious to boot from volume users that they need to do this.   Would appreciate further thoughts on this.


Johannes: Also, can the interval and retries be pushed up to the user control?  For instance, if the client wants a clean shutdown, they could request a clean power off (adds one flag to the API). Retries (requesting another clean power off) and timeouts (moving on to hard power off or other operation) could be handled by the client as well.

By making it possible to control the timeout and retries optional image metadata values I am giving the user some control where they own the image (and its really the characteristics of the image that determine what behaviour is needed).    Polling for whether the Guest has shutdown or not back up at the client would be very expensive in terms of the amount of API and RPC interaction - most Linux guests that have completed their boot do shutdown within a few seconds at the first time of asking providing, so I think exposing the timing and retries outside the virt layer adds a lot more complexity than is required.   From the feedback we've had most users just want to be able to ask for a clean shutdown - and are surprised that they don't get one for stop, etc."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-04-23 12:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (20 inline comments)

+1 for Daniel's comment on image metadata."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2014-05-21 18:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

It sounds like the general consensus is to do something by default on the server side and I agree with that after this conversation. We should strive to make it easy for users to do the right thing.

My biggest concern is that policy decisions can be complicated. Making a complicated policy can make Nova complicated. Making it simple means that more complicated policy needs to be implemented client side anyway.

The existing proposal provides a somewhat complicated way of controlling timeouts and retries, but it doesn't provide a way for a user to control policy to do something more complicated.

I'd like to look at a hybrid approach where a simple default policy can be done server side, but anything more complicated is done by the client.

Default to always doing a "soft" shutdown before anything that controls power state. Image metadata can override the default (where it's known the image won't respond to shutdown). User request can override the image metadata (called "shutdown_type").

If "soft" is specified, then shutdown is request once and after a timeout, it does a "hard" shutdown.

The stop request also includes a "timeout". Setting it to 0 returns immediately and does not fallback to "hard".

Leave everything else for the client to do. They can do complicated policy if they want to without making Nova more complicated. They can use the stop request with a 0 timeout to do anything more complicated.

I think that's a reasonable set of default behavior, fairly simple while allowing the user to do something more complicated if they want.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-22 13:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-22 13:41:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

>The existing proposal provides a somewhat complicated way of controlling timeouts and retries, but it doesn't provide a way for a user to control policy to do something more complicated.
I'd like to look at a hybrid approach where a simple default policy can be done server side, but anything more complicated is done by the client.

I'm not sure how that would work in practice - its easy to have the complexity at the server side and then simplfy that into a "do the policy or do nothing" exposed to the client - but you have to have at least the same set of options exposed all the way up the stack.   Remember to the user a Stop is an async call that always leaves the instance powered off one way on another - not something you can really build client side policy around.

What I tried to do with this BP is:
 - Always do the right thing by default in Nova (give the Guest a chance to shutdown)
 - Provide just enough complexity in the server (you have to wait, and you have to retry while waiting - that's the only approach that works)
 - Allow the owner of the image to fine tune that behaviour (as the timing will vary between Windows and Linux)
 - Allow the owner of the server an option to force a shutdown if they want to

That still feels like a pretty good balance to me'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-05-22 13:44:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

>I don't think image properties would remove the need for the API changes. At most I'd see an image property as a way to indicate that this image doesn't do graceful shutdown. ie a way to avoiding waiting for a timeout you know will never come.

I see image properties as doing a bit more than that - they allow the shutdown to be tuned based on how the image behaves (Windows vs Linux in terms of time to wait is a big difference).  This is Image specific rather than instance  /user specific."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-09 16:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-09 16:35:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Overall I think having the control is good. However it seems like the reason that this is getting hit is that what's really going on is different images really imply different acpi behavior.

Which makes me wonder if this is better done by applying metadata to the images. Then the image creator could express that this kind of image really needs to be treated with kid gloves (i.e. windows) vs. this kind of image is completely broken on acpi (i.e. cirros) so "soft" isn't ever going to work anyway.

If it was done at an image level, that would also allow snapshots to have specific extra flags of "this is windows 7 with a database, so we *really* want to wait a long time", for instance.

It's a different approach, but I think would let the system more often do the right thing, and not make it slow all the time in situations that should be fast.'}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2014-06-25 12:36:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2014-06-25 13:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-25 13:28:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

@Sean - I have already covered in the BP that this can be configured by the image metadata - but I think we still have to have some default values in the system for all the existing images that won't (yet) have the right metadata properties.  I'm not really sure that there is a good case for only making this configurable via image metadata ?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-25 13:33:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Remember that the current behaviour which can lead to data corruption in the guest is a pretty significant bug.

I kind of feel that we're spinning on nits here about whether there should only be one way to configure a subset of the possible values needed to make this work - when the BP as it stands tries to make it as comprehensive as possible in response to the various requests that were made both earlier in this spec review and against the code that was originally merged.  

I don't see any real convergence now between the various arguments for different subsets of options, but equally no-one is saying that as presented it doesn't meet their use cases - so I'd like to move ahead as it stands if possible, otherwise I think we'll still be here in K"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-06-25 13:35:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

If you remove the unneccesary option for changing the interval of pokes, I'm +2 on this spec"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-25 17:10:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

@Daniel - See above,  For everyone that wants one subset of options there is someone that wants a different subset ;-) 

This has to have a default value - I really don't feel confident hard coding it for all possible environments where Openstack is going to be deployed.

I do understand the complexity that config options bring (I'm a major deployer as well as a developer remember) - so this isn't there without some consideration.

I kind of find your hard line on this one option a bit hard to understand when your're happy to add multiple extra-specs   options for the various libvirt BPs while recongising that some of those may never be used ?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2014-06-25 18:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-25 21:29:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I checked with one of our folks who build and support our windows images, and their recommendation is that depending on what's running in the image (in particular SQL server) you should allow several minutes for the shutdown and only poke it every 30 seconds or so.   

SO I get that this might seem like a pointless configuration option for Linux images, but I still believe there is a reason for it as at least an image property.

So as a compromise how about if its a fixed value in the code (rather than a config setting) but can be over-ridden by image metadata ?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-06-26 13:15:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

May be I'm missing something that isn't being explained here, but AFAICT this still does not describe *any* functional impact or benefit of making the poke interval configurable.

Lets consider if we hardcode the poke interval at 10 seconds, and we have a configurable upper timeout of 2 minutes. There will be 12 poke attempts during that 2 minute window. Each time we poke the guest during this 2 minute window we have the following possible behaviour

  - If the guest isn't set todo anything with ACPI power signals
        => Nothing happens
  - Else
      - If the guest missed a previous poke
          => Start shutdown operation
      - Else (if the guest is already shutting down)
          => Continue previous shutdown operation

What actual real *functional* impact is there to making the poke interval configurable ?  If we default the interval to 10 seconds, and the admin overrides to to be every 30 seconds, the same logic is going to take place in the guest. The only functional impact is that if the guest missed the first poke, there will be an even longer delay before the next poke triggers shutdown.

The only real interesting scenario here is what happens when the guest receives a poke and it is already shutting down. Lets say, for argument sake, there was some negative consequence to receiving another poke request when already shutting down, such as the existing shutdown task getting aborted. If we make the interval configurable so the user specifies 30 seconds instead of 10 seconds. If the guest is taking 2 minutes to shutdown, this hasn't avoided the problem - you're still going to hit that negative consequence up to 4 times.

If anyone can show a clearly useful functional impact of making the poke interval configurable, I'll be happy to approve it. So far though no one has shown any benefit to making poke interval configurable, over just fixing it to poke every 10 seconds.."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-26 13:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-26 13:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Daniel.

If I expand your scenario to the case where a repoke doesn't abort/restart the shutdown cycle but does slow it down, then as the image owner I would want to be able to tune that to make an informed trade-off between the latency of getting the first poke noticed, and the impact of making an inprogress shutdown slower.

This is a *user* decision (they are the only ones affected) - and they can express that decision via image metadata.

The proportion of GuestOS's / users that need this is somewhere on the scale of very few to None - but that's against a pretty much unbonded set.   We provide a reasonably small set of images in our public cloud, and on that sample I wouldn't want to rule this out.

What we can be sure of is if we don't expose this at all to users,  and the only way to empower such a user is via a code change that's a pretty long cycle /poor user experience.   That's why I want to still keep the door open on control via image metadata.  I really don't see that is a high price to pay in terms of the delta system or image complexity."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-06-26 16:20:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

This is still is an entirely hypothetical problem. I simply don't think we should be adding code to solve a problem when we don't even know whether the problem exists in the first place."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2014-06-26 17:00:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I think you're overstating the complexity and code that this adds.  The values have to exist whatever their source, and at least one of the values needs to be settable via image metadata - so the additional code here amounts to looking for one additional image metadata value.

Doing that to reduce the risk that this might break someone on one of the many production deployments now out there seems like a very very small price to me."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2014-07-10 23:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I'm not sure I see the value add of the configurable retry interval either. What is the reason having a longer interval would help in some cases? Does it hurt to send "too many" shutdown signals to the guest?

Other than that, I'd really like to see this functionality added. I have observed a problematic number of guest file system corruptions because of the lack of a graceful shutdown.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-10 23:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Verified

'}, {'created': '2014-06-09 16:35:17.000000000', 'message': 'Allow controlled shutdown of GuestOS for operations which power off the VM

Powering off a VM without giving the Guest Operating system a chance
to perform a controlled shutdown can lead to data corruption.

The proposed changes will make the default behavior for stop, rescue, resize,
and shelve to give the GuestOS a chance to perform a controlled shutdown
before the VM is powered off.

The change will encapsulate the complexity of signaling to and waiting for
the GuestOS in the hypervisor, and allow image owners the ability to tune
the associated timing via image metadata to take account of GuestOSs that
require an extended period to shutdown (such as Windows).

Users will be able to specify the shutdown behavior on a per operation basis
via a new shutdown_type parameter where, in keeping with the current reboot
operation, a "soft" shutdown will give the GuestOS a chance to perform a
clean shutdown, and a "hard" shutdown will cause an immediate power off.  The
default behavior will be a "soft" shutdown.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/user-defined-shutdown

Change-Id: Ie2c13c9173566c6d545fcaf6a3ab88df636a7d33

commit_message:
Allow controlled shutdown of GuestOS for operations which power off the VM

Powering off a VM without giving the Guest Operating system a chance
to perform a controlled shutdown can lead to data corruption.

The proposed changes will make the default behavior for stop, rescue, resize,
and shelve to give the GuestOS a chance to perform a controlled shutdown
before the VM is powered off.

The change will encapsulate the complexity of signaling to and waiting for
the GuestOS in the hypervisor, and allow image owners the ability to tune
the associated timing via image metadata to take account of GuestOSs that
require an extended period to shutdown (such as Windows).

Users will be able to specify the shutdown behavior on a per operation basis
via a new shutdown_type parameter where, in keeping with the current reboot
operation, a "soft" shutdown will give the GuestOS a chance to perform a
clean shutdown, and a "hard" shutdown will cause an immediate power off.  The
default behavior will be a "soft" shutdown.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/user-defined-shutdown

Change-Id: Ie2c13c9173566c6d545fcaf6a3ab88df636a7d33

commit_message:
Fixes incorrect assertion check

assertNotIn/assertIn does not work if the second
variable is of type List of dictionaries.
Suppose if it of only dictionary type, it will try
to match only 'key' but not 'value'.
Hence, the assertion check done here is not correct.

This patch fixes an incorrect assertion check for
"BasicOperationsImagesTest.test_delete_image" test

Change-Id: I7058d209cc92a2e381308e59e07d180e84bde182
Closes-Bug: #1346757

commit_message:
Correct revocation event test for domain_id

The revocation event test used "user_domain_id" and
"project_domain_id" as token fields that the "domain_id"
revocation event field maps to, but the token fields are
actually "identity_domain_id" and "assignment_domain_id", as
can be seen in
keystone.contrib.revoke.model.build_token_values().

Change-Id: I208484da243403287eaa33893d57429c7e6d27c7
Partial-Bug: #1349597

commit_message:
Add glance notifications tests for ceilometer

Added ceilometer test for measurements:
image.update, image.upload, image.delete, image.download, image.serve

measurements: image, image.size are not added to tests because they 
have status 'both', these measurements are pollster and notification
ones at the same time.

Partially implements: blueprint add-basic-ceilometer-tests

Change-Id: Id049b6cb8ab3092c50f35894cf5a6bda7ff04617

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-16 18:06:27.000000000', 'message': 'Policy Enforcer, pass entire context dict

The oslo enforcer expects "as much detail as possible" about the
calling user in the creds dict, so include the whole context dict,
which will enable more complex policy rules to be expressed than
with the current code where we pass only a subset of the context
data.

Change-Id: I70bd0fb07bb0b8e9c3c2b94b399197ad207d0fd2
'}]
commit_message:
Policy Enforcer, pass entire context dict

The oslo enforcer expects "as much detail as possible" about the
calling user in the creds dict, so include the whole context dict,
which will enable more complex policy rules to be expressed than
with the current code where we pass only a subset of the context
data.

Change-Id: I70bd0fb07bb0b8e9c3c2b94b399197ad207d0fd2

Since oslosphinx is out, let's use it instead of hosting our own
themes and static files.

Change-Id: I5b507d35c90d0c0411d7751935b0e53328ca9311

commit_message:
Use oslosphinx to generate doc theme

Since oslosphinx is out, let's use it instead of hosting our own
themes and static files.

Change-Id: I5b507d35c90d0c0411d7751935b0e53328ca9311

Guys, that change reverts Murano migration engine from alembic to sqlalchemy-migrate (more precisely, calling the right engine). It is actually a fix for the Murano until alembic migrations are merged (https://gerrit.mirantis.com/#/c/18948/). The catch is that we need this alembic migration patch in 5.1 very much, so we'd better merge them first and everything will be fine with current puppet script for Murano."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2014-07-29 09:45:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Update_port should expect MACAlreadyExists

Conductor manager's update_port() method should include
exception.MACAlreadyExists in the list of expected exceptions.  This
will stop logging it as a traceback on the Conductor when a client
attempts to update a port and change its address to one that is already
registered.

Change-Id: Ic575e03da566c7b44bf6b72ac171633d80165ffc
Closes-Bug: #1348676

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-25 10:04:18.000000000', 'message': "Sync RPC module from oslo

This change syncs the following patches from stable/havana oslo RPC:
- I67923cb024bbd143edc8edccf35b9b400df31eb3
- Ia148baa6e1ec632789ac3621c85173c2c16f3918

RabbitMQ: advance thru the list of brokers on reconnect

In RabbitMQ implementation, when using multiple rabbit_hosts, we don't want to
immediately retry failed connection for the same failed broker. This was not
the case in existing implementation though, where we've always attempted to
reconnect starting from the first broker in the list of candidates. So if the
first broker failed, we initiated reconnect to the same failed broker.

This change makes reconnect() implementation to select the next broker in the
list. This also means that non-failure reconnect attempts will also switch the
current broker. All in all, users should not rely on any particular order to
use brokers from the list, so this should not constitute an issue.

Qpid: advance thru the list of brokers on reconnect

In Qpid implementation, when using multiple qpid_hosts, we don't want to
immediately retry failed connection for the same failed broker. This was not
the case in existing implementation though, where we've always attempted to
reconnect starting from the first broker in the list of candidates. So if the
first broker failed, we initiated reconnect to the same failed broker.

This change makes reconnect() implementation to select the next broker in the
list. This also means that non-failure reconnect attempts will also switch the
current broker. All in all, users should not rely on any particular order to
use brokers from the list, so this should not constitute an issue.

Partial-Bug: #1261631
Change-Id: Icde6b3a1fa173be2a3ccc729b7ed739dd4f4aa11
"}]
commit_message:
Sync RPC module from oslo

This change syncs the following patches from stable/havana oslo RPC:
- I67923cb024bbd143edc8edccf35b9b400df31eb3
- Ia148baa6e1ec632789ac3621c85173c2c16f3918

RabbitMQ: advance thru the list of brokers on reconnect

In RabbitMQ implementation, when using multiple rabbit_hosts, we don't want to
immediately retry failed connection for the same failed broker. This was not
the case in existing implementation though, where we've always attempted to
reconnect starting from the first broker in the list of candidates. So if the
first broker failed, we initiated reconnect to the same failed broker.

This change makes reconnect() implementation to select the next broker in the
list. This also means that non-failure reconnect attempts will also switch the
current broker. All in all, users should not rely on any particular order to
use brokers from the list, so this should not constitute an issue.

Qpid: advance thru the list of brokers on reconnect

In Qpid implementation, when using multiple qpid_hosts, we don't want to
immediately retry failed connection for the same failed broker. This was not
the case in existing implementation though, where we've always attempted to
reconnect starting from the first broker in the list of candidates. So if the
first broker failed, we initiated reconnect to the same failed broker.

This change makes reconnect() implementation to select the next broker in the
list. This also means that non-failure reconnect attempts will also switch the
current broker. All in all, users should not rely on any particular order to
use brokers from the list, so this should not constitute an issue.

Partial-Bug: #1261631
Change-Id: Icde6b3a1fa173be2a3ccc729b7ed739dd4f4aa11

I don't have a good sense of what drives the timing of things, but overall the goal is Juno.  If the more comprehensive version can make it to Juno, why can't this patch just be dependent on that one?"}, {'account_id': 11279, 'date': '2014-07-17 04:40:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I have a string of other changes queued up behind each other :(

For this one in particular, it affects whether the devstack change needs to manually specify raise_on_warnings=false on the db uri, which in turn makes that change more complicated (since it's the only query option that would vary by db choice).  Fixing it correctly in oslo means I don't have to work around it in the downstream project(s).

And on a more personal level filled with first world problems, each submission delay means I have to come back and maintain the outstanding patch periodically, which saps time (check it rebases, whether the dependencies are now satisfied and I should go find reviewers, or even just identifying and skipping over this change when looking at the list of my outstanding patches).

That's why it matters to me ;)"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2014-07-17 15:35:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

if fixing it here right now means that a downstream devstack patch can be avoided, then that is the better case.   though if roman can just add a couple of tests to his patch then we can push that out and the whole conga line can go through.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-21 01:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

I've verified this version is correct by hacking up the MysqlOpportunistic test to use mysqlconnector and installing mysqlconnector into the venv (and temporarily disabling TestConnectionUtils.test_connect_string).  The tox mysql tests use mysqlconnector and pass successfully - and they fail if I remove the raise_on_warnings line.

I spent quite a while trying to create a test case and failed without additional major surgery on the session.create_engine code, or the mysql-connector-python module being installed.  In particular, the new compat.handle_error code contains a check that the argument is a specific type, which defeats my earlier naive mock.
Using Mock(spec=Engine) passes that test, but then I need to explicitly create a number of additional instance attributes to satisfy the surrounding sqlalchemy code - and I felt I was getting too far into specific sqlalchemy implementation details at that point.  So .. there is no additional automated test for this change."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-22 05:33:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

for raise_on_warnings.  With raise_on_warnings=True, many things we

commit_message:
Specify raise_on_warnings=False for mysqlconnector

mysqlconnector driver in sqlalchemy <1.0 uses the wrong default value
for raise_on_warnings.  With raise_on_warnings=True, many things we
expect to be warnings become fatal (like DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS
non_existent_db).

See https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/sqlalchemy/issue/2515 for upstream bug.

Change-Id: Ic29c9bb6c692952640e3948f5ce31290e158068f

commit_message:
Upgrades, fixed host system upgrader

Switch /etc/fuel/version.yaml to new
version when run host system upgrade
engine because puppet relies on this
file.

This change fixes the bug, when user
runs upgrade several times and puppet
overwrites supervisor configs for
previous version.

Change-Id: I79ff27bb5078d0cf885612af0560b9e1623c6206
Closes-bug: #1349286

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-26 01:26:44.000000000', 'message': 'Removed extra work in case of no volumes

Before the change the following actions were performed even if there
are no volumes to attach:
1. thread spawn
2. roundtrip to instance to make sure that there are 0 volumes attached
3. roundtrip to nova to get assigned volumes

Change-Id: I3f120cb5e60b2c8b2439c7f4acc7b99ce4964895
'}]
commit_message:
Removed extra work in case of no volumes

Before the change the following actions were performed even if there
are no volumes to attach:
1. thread spawn
2. roundtrip to instance to make sure that there are 0 volumes attached
3. roundtrip to nova to get assigned volumes

oslo.db.api module documentation

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-23 01:25:54.000000000', 'message': "Handle error from execute() when deleting non-existant file

Code inspection around an exception found a piece of code handling an
error from execute_with_timeout() in a problematic way. A call was
made to delete a file and if the file did not exist,
execute_with_timeout() would throw an exception. However, 'rm' is not
very friendly, and only returns 0, -1, +1 and not errno
(ENOENT). Therefore the code was (literally) looking in stdout for the
string 'No such file or directory'.

The recommended way of handling missing files with rm is to use the
command line '-f' option which will suppress errors on nonexistent
files. The mechanism of searching for a literal string is not good for
a couple of reasons but the most significant two are that it requires
a thrown exception (which would get logged as an exception), and that
in languages other than English, the error string would be something
else (not 'No such file ...').

A test to ensure that wipe_ib_logfiles() properly suppressed the
exception is now redundant and has been deleted.

Change-Id: Ie99a0843d1e388d508a904fca0a759ca8bcd9f26
Partial-Bug: #1346879

commit_message:
Handle error from execute() when deleting non-existant file

Code inspection around an exception found a piece of code handling an
error from execute_with_timeout() in a problematic way. A call was
made to delete a file and if the file did not exist,
execute_with_timeout() would throw an exception. However, 'rm' is not
very friendly, and only returns 0, -1, +1 and not errno
(ENOENT). Therefore the code was (literally) looking in stdout for the
string 'No such file or directory'.

The recommended way of handling missing files with rm is to use the
command line '-f' option which will suppress errors on nonexistent
files. The mechanism of searching for a literal string is not good for
a couple of reasons but the most significant two are that it requires
a thrown exception (which would get logged as an exception), and that
in languages other than English, the error string would be something
else (not 'No such file ...').

A test to ensure that wipe_ib_logfiles() properly suppressed the
exception is now redundant and has been deleted.

Change-Id: Ie99a0843d1e388d508a904fca0a759ca8bcd9f26
Partial-Bug: #1346879

commit_message:
labs: actually call MySQL in setup_openstackdb

The code in setup_openstackdb has been left in debug mode, which means
it just echoed the mysql commands rather than executing them.

This patches fixes that.

Change-Id: I261a65a9c0ff147803649aeb750f397826730934

@Dmitry, AFAICT, __all__ limits the importable symbols, but doesn't have any magic to resolve a string, eg 'client', into the module path. That's why I am both importing them and then adding them to __all__. But I may be wrong...

@Ruby, yea. Too late, though this gives us an easier mechanism to move to that. Eg, we could create two references to exc.py, and then rename the actual module, and the API I'm proposing here wouldn't change. But if we just rename exc.py -> exception.py, anyone using this package will be broken."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2014-07-23 19:15:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Export 'client' and 'exc' modules

To facilitate cleaner importing of this package,
explicitly export the 'client' and 'exc' modules. Also add
in an exported alias for 'exc' called 'exceptions' to help
migrate away from the user-unfriendly 'exc' name.

Co-authored-by: Michael Davies <michael@the-davies.net>

Change-Id: I59ea5c439dbf6ff30cc65cf95491b47bbbd0c516

commit_message:
Fix the issue with multiple agent call

This patch fixes the issue related to execution of the same execution plan on
multiple VMs. The root cause was agent handling code which overwrites template
with execution plan.
Now template is deep copied before execution plan creation.
Thanks to Stan to help to fix that.

Change-Id: I1d101ab155c46986ac4eed0e53beed7c8df1b569
Closes-Bug: #1335929

The libvirt-daemon-driver-network pulls the dnsmasq,
on hosts where the n-cpu installed with libvirt backend.

commit_message:
[Fedora] Install dnsmasq on n-cpu less host

The libvirt-daemon-driver-network pulls the dnsmasq,
on hosts where the n-cpu installed with libvirt backend.

But nothing installs it if you have only n-net or q-dhcp,
on the given hosts.

dnsmasq-utils does not depends on dnsmasq,
because it can work with other local dhcp servers.

Change-Id: I17a769df3bd51ca608c1728e892009125eea42ed

commit_message:
Add missing dns domain for venv.pp

Dns domain option is missing in nailgun::venv
class call and definition.
Its value is needed for settings.yaml.erb in
order to config DNS_DOMAIN and DNS_SEARCH and must
be passed as a class param.

Closes bug: #1346939

Change-Id: I5c8ebf6c66383ba1841190c80bd1fbc64afa2a39
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Add missing dns domain for venv.pp

Dns domain option is missing in nailgun::venv
class call and definition.
Its value is needed for settings.yaml.erb in
order to config DNS_DOMAIN and DNS_SEARCH and must
be passed as a class param.

Closes bug: #1346939

commit_message:
allow RadosGW and Ceph/RBD for Glance with vCenter

Only Ceph storage backends for Cinder and Nova should be disabled when
vCenter is used as the hypervisor, Ceph can still be used as storage
backend for Glance and for Swift/S3 object storage.

Change-Id: I5b77ad0a98673e331a5c3e5e7652c30ae2a96354
Closes-Bug: #1316377

commit_message:
Define asserts for python 2.6

Frequent issue a test case is failing with py26,
because the used assert methods
is not defined.

Adding unittest2.TestCase to the base testclass when running
tests with py26.

Change-Id: I1116f99dadeb94da9deb9d31d58e42c5d44ff664
Closes-bug: #1333164

commit_message:
autohelp: make sure that oslo.i18n is setup

Some module imports fail without a proper setup of oslo.i18n, so make
sure that it is the case for projects using this package.

Change-Id: I7082cb893ccb52fa7bf065a01655efb9a5bbd4e2

commit_message:
virt: force TCG with libguestfs unless KVM is enabled in libvirt

If the libvirt driver has not been configured to use KVM, then
the libguestfs module should be forced to use TCG. This is
particularly important when running Nova inside a VM, which
might claim to have VMX/SVM support when it is in fact broken.
This will avoid libguestfs hanging in such scenarios.

Resolves-bug: #1286256
Change-Id: I9316dcedd65244c60d468b270311f032b45b051f

subject: virt: move disk tests into a sub-directory

commit_message:
virt: move disk tests into a sub-directory

The test_virt_disk.py, test_virt_disk_vfs_guestfs.py, and
test_virt_disk_vfs_localfs.py test cases were in the top
level nova/tests/virt directory. Current policy is to use
a directory location that matches the source being tested,
so they should be in either nova/tests/virt/disk or
nova/tests/virt/disk/vfs respectively. The test_loop.py
and test_nbd.py tests should be in nova/tests/virt/disk/mount
too. Finally fakeguestfs.py should also be kept in the
nova/tests/virt/disk/vfs directory

Change-Id: Iebee539d202d5122939ae478fd482f19b19f604d

subject: Replace str() with six.text_type() where exception is used

commit_message:
Replace str() with six.text_type() where exception is used

When switching to oslo.i18n, tests where used str(exc) will failed
with unicodeerror, so before switching to oslo.i18n, need to
replace str with six.text_type where exception is used. And it's
recommanded to use six.text_type instead of str in openstack.

Change-Id: Ie37a6ef74a12b2580ce72afc75c99bcd19d4cf97

commit_message:
Move libvirt RBD utilities to a new file

This will make it easier to share rbd-related code with cinder and glance.
Port the applicable unit tests over from cinder.

Closes-Bug: #1346092
Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Borodaenko <dborodaenko@mirantis.com>
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>
Signed-off-by: Dmitry Borodaenko <dborodaenko@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I614b8e2bf0ea9e71a73772cbabcf812b39fa8a34

subject: Use library instead of CLI to cleanup RBD volumes

Hmm, so there's a couple issues that have cropped up with this (good) patch.

1) Due to some changes recently introduced, there is a failure with the Ironic contract that is causing a unit test failure:

 ft1.10026:  nova.tests.virt.test_ironic_api_contracts.IronicAPIContractsTestCase.test_ComputeDriver_signatures_StringException: Empty attachments:
  pythonlogging:''
  stderr
  stdout
 
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "nova/tests/virt/test_ironic_api_contracts.py", line 95, in test_ComputeDriver_signatures
    'block_device_info', 'destroy_disks'])
  File "nova/tests/virt/test_ironic_api_contracts.py", line 28, in _check_method
    "%s() violates Ironic contract" % str_version)
  File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-python26/.tox/py26/lib/python2.6/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 321, in assertEqual
    self.assertThat(observed, matcher, message)
  File "/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-python26/.tox/py26/lib/python2.6/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 406, in assertThat
    raise mismatch_error
MismatchError: !=:
reference = ['self',
 'context',
 'instance',
 'network_info',
 'block_device_info',
 'destroy_disks']
actual    = ['self',
 'context',
 'instance',
 'network_info',
 'block_device_info',
 'destroy_disks',
 'migrate_data']
: ComputeDriver.destroy() violates Ironic contract

2) Unfortunately, the root patch in this patch series has been deemed to be too small in scope by Dan Berrange and Matt Riedemann, so unfortunately, the chances of getting this code in are slim at this point.

I would suggest that the most efficient way of getting this into master would be to detach it from the dependent patches and submit as an independent patch...

Best,

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-05-20 02:16:18.000000000', 'message': "Use library instead of CLI to cleanup RBD volumes

'rbd list' CLI returns error code when there are no rbd volumes, which
causes problems during live migration of VMs with RBD backed ephemeral
volumes. It's safer to use the library that only raises an exception in
case of a real problem.

The only case where rbd CLI is still justified is import, which is
needed to correctly import sparse image files.

All code related to cleanup of RBD volumes is moved to rbd_utils.py,
this fixes a yo-yo problem with single-use methods scattered across 3
different files, and minimizes impact of this fix on imports in
imagebackend and utils.

Flake8 F401 in test_libvirt.py has to be ignored since flake8 doesn't
recognize use of an imported module in a @mock.patch decorator.

blueprint rbd-clone-image-handler
Change-Id: I92cd6b16fbd93b377fe47b15d22efbbf68d02513
Signed-off-by: Dmitry Borodaenko <dborodaenko@mirantis.com>

"}, {'created': '2014-05-23 07:59:50.000000000', 'message': "Use library instead of CLI to cleanup RBD volumes

'rbd list' CLI returns error code when there are no rbd volumes, which
causes problems during live migration of VMs with RBD backed ephemeral
volumes. It's safer to use the library that only raises an exception in
case of a real problem.

The only case where rbd CLI is still justified is import, which is
needed to correctly import sparse image files.

All code related to cleanup of RBD volumes is moved to rbd_utils.py,
this fixes a yo-yo problem with single-use methods scattered across 3
different files, and minimizes impact of this fix on imports in
imagebackend and utils.

Flake8 F401 in test_libvirt.py has to be ignored since flake8 doesn't
recognize use of an imported module in a @mock.patch decorator.

blueprint rbd-clone-image-handler
Change-Id: I92cd6b16fbd93b377fe47b15d22efbbf68d02513
Signed-off-by: Dmitry Borodaenko <dborodaenko@mirantis.com>

Signed-off-by: Dmitry Borodaenko <dborodaenko@mirantis.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Use library instead of CLI to cleanup RBD volumes

'rbd list' CLI returns error code when there are no rbd volumes, which
causes problems during live migration of VMs with RBD backed ephemeral
volumes. It's safer to use the library that only raises an exception in
case of a real problem.

The only case where rbd CLI is still justified is import, which is
needed to correctly import sparse image files.

All code related to cleanup of RBD volumes is moved to rbd.py, this
fixes a yo-yo problem with single-use methods scattered across 3
different files, and minimizes impact of this fix on imports in
imagebackend and utils.

Closes-Bug: #1346092
Change-Id: I92cd6b16fbd93b377fe47b15d22efbbf68d02513
Signed-off-by: Dmitry Borodaenko <dborodaenko@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Automatic discovery of TripleO Overcloud hardware

-geting IP addresses from Undercloud nova, allowing
 to poll all Overcloud nodes via SNMP
-adding support of basic auth, user_name and password
 used in TripleO by default

Change-Id: I189dbba9579055c8a1a878a769760a72e9174c6d

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8978, 'date': '2014-06-16 10:13:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I am very happy to see that blueprint under review!

However, I feel we are missing couple of crucial things in the proposal. 

It's not clear from the blueprint how the full workflow would look like. I know it was described in the 'old' blueprint, so I would paste it here and let others weigh in. Also, here are some issues that in my opinion should be addressed here:

- how does the service catalog in the token change
- where is the token scoped to a certain project/domain (remote nova expects a scoped token if I am correct, how issuing, local Keystone should know what remote projects/domains/roles are available?)
- I assume a token issued by a local Keystone can be proof of identity, how do we combine it with federation protocols (like SAML)?"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2014-06-16 16:06:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I have some concerns about this spec. It feels like it's inverted.

The user gets a token issued from the internal keystone that is valid on the external keystone from my understanding. This is not the normal workflow for the SAML or OpenID etc auth. I also think it is unreasonable to "know" the endpoints of the external cloud.

Usually authentication with federation would work like:

* User asks external keystone for token
* External keystone initiates authentication
* User authenticates, via redirect/etc to the internal keystone
* An appropriate authentication response (e.g. SAML assertion) would be issued and handed off to the external keystone
* external keystone now has authn and identity information to issue token (authz)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2014-06-16 16:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 1228, 'date': '2014-06-16 21:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

Quick convo via IRC:

<jsavak> review is: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/100023/
<jsavak> major concerns seem to be security, re-creating the wheel, and confusion about service provider vs idp, right?
<stevemar> jsavak, jorgew i think morganfainberg wants to know why don't we just use pysaml and make keystone issue saml assertions?
<morganfainberg> jorgew, yeah.
<morganfainberg> stevemar, ++ also marekd had similar thoughts
<morganfainberg> afaict
<jorgew> morganfainberg,  I think we want to allow users to burst to other clouds without dealing with the idocyncraisis of the SAML protocol directly and to contiune to use the same tools.
<jorgew> morganfainberg, Also there is a good use case for having the user not even know they are bursting…think resellers.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, but what is being proposed is opening potential security concerns, the external cloud needs to trust the the internal cloud implictly
<morganfainberg> jorgew, an internal cloud issuing tokens on behalf of an external cloud is risky
<jsavak> morganfainberg - the trust is explicit. Must be setup within both internal and external cloud
<jorgew> morganfainberg,  How is that different than regular federation.  If someone compromises the IDP then that person can send assertions, get tokens right?
<morganfainberg> jorgew, there is a difference between accepting an authentication from a remote source and authorization
<jorgew> jsavak, right, trust should not be given lightly.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, most federation is authentication only.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, the service (in this case the external cloud) would still handle the authz part
<morganfainberg> jorgew, this proposal puts both authn and authz on a remote, not in control of the local cloud, service
<morganfainberg> jorgew, that is my #1 concern. I have some other concerns on this being a new "protocol" (using keystone tokens to transit data?) or if it's SAML or OpenID on the backend, how is that negotiation initiated
<morganfainberg> jorgew, because those usually require user-interaction
<morganfainberg> jorgew s/user/client
<jorgew> morganfainberg,  The proposal is not suggesting that we do anything different in terms of federation than we are now.  Only to hide some of the flow (or orchestration) for handling SAML stuff.  Authz continues to work as it does now.
<morganfainberg> CaioBrentano, i'll look in a moment.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, that is not clear, it looks like authz is being provided by the internal cloud
<morganfainberg> jorgew, not by the external cloud
<morganfainberg> jorgew, which Keystone is issuing the token that is meant to be used in the external cloud?
<jorgew> morganfainberg, the underling protocols remain the same.  The issue is how we hook things together, maybe we need to make that more clear in the blueprint.
<jorgew> morganfainberg, it depends on how you setup the relationships :-)
<jorgew> morganfainberg, one keystone can act as an identity provider, that is the one that issues the token.
<jorgew> morganfainberg, in otherwords the keystone that knows about the user.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, ok assume the IDP is internal keystone, SP is external
<jorgew> morganfainberg, k
<morganfainberg> jorgew, walk me through the auth steps please. (sorry, just trying to understand the proposal here so we can make it clear)
<jorgew> morganfainberg, no worries and to be honest we need to work this out as well…but here's how I see it…
<jorgew> morganfainberg, off line there is a relationship established between IDP and SP via some magic keys are echanged and mappings are made.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, ok.
<jorgew> morganfainberg, when a user logs in to IDP they get a service catalog that has endpoints from SP.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, so this is User authenticates with internal keystone here, and gets a token back
<morganfainberg> ?
<jorgew> morganfainberg, correct.  The token can then be used to hit the SP endpoint.
<morganfainberg> and here is where we're now insecure
<jorgew> morganfainberg, the SP may introspect the token, know that it came from the IDP and know there is a trust there.
<morganfainberg> the way the middleware works, if the token is considered valid, it is valid and trusted
<morganfainberg> so either you're then asking the external keystone on every action if it is a "valid token", or you trust it, and internal idp can issue tokens for anything in the entire external cloud
<jorgew> morganfainberg, obviously, we'll have to change middleware to deal with trusts between clouds….maybe that's what we're missing in the spec
<morganfainberg> jorgew, i think this is backwards
<morganfainberg> jorgew, the external cloud should still issue the token
<morganfainberg> just the authn and identity (user/group) bits should come from internal
<jorgew> morganfainberg, the middle ware will need to understand what certs it accepts and validate the tokens much as it does now
<morganfainberg> yes, it is a better UX, but what you're proposing would be like if google+ had an agreement with FB, but instead of when you login to google+ it redirects you to FB, it would just grab all your private data from FB, never asking because you authenticated w/ Google+.
<jorgew> morganfainberg, can you explain how that is more sucure than the other.?
<morganfainberg> redirect in that scenario would be you needing to auth the request on fb's site.
<morganfainberg> jorgew, if the internal keystone just offers the identity bits, the workflow looks like this
<morganfainberg> user requests token from external cloud's keystone
<morganfainberg> wait..

Clear terminology would definitely be beneficial going forward.  I think the main distinction to make is the "User's Keystone" vs. the "Service Provider's Keystone".

Here's another use case:

**Use Case 4:  Storage-only Provisioning**

A service provider wishes to provide only storage services to external users.  Hence, in any federation, the SP must be able to "advertize" only it's Swift service endpoints, and no others.  Furthermore, the storage provider may wish to enforce access policies (who can access which containers) based on the set of roles that it defines.  Hence, the User's Keystone must be able to acquire this set of roles and assign them to users accordingly.


Allowing ACME to poll BETA is essentially the approach of building the Service Catalog returned to the user from the project-filtered endpoints from all of the federated domain instances at each participating Keystone.

I think it is critical to make "federation" as consistent as possible with the current object model exposed to the user, and used to manage the user's actions.  When a user authn's to their local Keystone, they should receive a Service Catalog that contains all service the user is authorized to see at any site participating in a federation.

Since service endpoints are filtered based on project membership, this implies that federation, imho, MUST be domain-specific.  That is to say, to federate two Keystones really means to federate two domains managed by those Keystones.  Furthermore, these two (or more) Keystones MUST agree on the projects defined within a federated domain for simple reasons of consistency: If User A is a member of Project P, then the Service Catalog returned with project-scope authentication will contain the endpoints for all Project Ps across the federated Domains.

This approach actually supports both unidirectional and bidirectional federation.  Federation is bidirectional if a Keystone makes both local users and local service endpoints available as part of federated domain.  If a Keystone makes _either_ users _or_ endpoints available, then the federation is unidirectional.

After discovering all services available in a Domain and Project, service authorization must also be done.  Since this is typically based on a User's roles, then the federated Keystones must agree on these roles and their meaning.  Given that roles are currently system-wide, this means potentially all Keystones everywhere (that might want to federate) would have to agree to what amounts to a
global set of roles.  I think it would be far more prudent and scalable to make roles domain-specific.  This way, all the elements needed to manage a federation are in one "container", i.e., a federated domain.


I like the approach of having the SP's Keystone query the User's Keystone.  It is another approach that I didn't include in my blueprint.  The User and Service Provider only interact with their local Keystones.  The User authenticates with their local Keystone, while the Service Provider validates the token with their local Keystone, as usual.  If the token is was not issued locally, then the
remote issuing Keystone must be queried.  While this introduces latency, it could be ameliorated with the usual techniques.


Wrt changes to the data model, the primary change would be to make roles domain-specific.


Wrt changes to the REST-ful API, Service Provider Register/List/Get/Delete/Update operations comprise the simplest "base case" API for managing federation.  This enables a system admin to manually manage one direction of a federation relationship.  For fully bidirectional federations, an API that supports interactions with a P2P agent could be considered -- but at some later date, not now.

As per my arguments above, however, this API should also identify the domains at each Keystone that are available for federation.  Likewise, the projects and roles within each potentially federated domain need to be defined.  This is critical for managing federations in a way that is completely consistent with the model of domains, projects, and roles that are currently exposed to users, and used to manage their actions.'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2014-06-24 15:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

As I was thinking about the idea of using a single token across multiple clouds I came up with a few more questions:

 - Are we or should we be concerned with information leakage? The token could contain a catalog, roles, etc. from CompanyA (local) and that information is available to CompanyB (remote). Even if we don't think that this information is secret enough to worry about I think that going forward we'll have to look at anything going into the token in this way to protect service providers.
 - Does this increase the surface area of an attack if a cloud is compromised?  For example, say CERN has a partnership with ProviderA and ProviderB to supplement its private cloud. A compromise of ProviderA is a Compromise of CERN and ProviderB at the token level."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2014-06-25 20:34:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-25 20:34:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9959, 'date': '2014-06-27 03:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I wrote these comments up on the plane ride home.  The line numbers might be a little off.  --Craig

L.82

This needs to be clarified.  Who is doing the cloud-bursting?  Is a
Cloud A User explicitly cloud-bursting to Cloud B, or is Cloud A
transparently cloud-bursting to Cloud B on behalf (and unbeknownst) to
the Cloud A User?  In this latter case, it seems that the Nova
Scheduler would have to know when and how to do this cloud-bursting
(assuming that only compute resources are required).

L.201

Assuming that a Keystone is manually configured to have a set of Trusted
Service Providers (TSPs), should all of these TSPs be exposed to every
User on every authentication?  How can only those TSPs be returned to
the User that the User is authorized to use (in some way)?

When a User authenticates to ACME, what is the scope of
authentication?  How does the scope of authentication relate to the
"scope" of federated resources?

If a set of AUTH_URLs for different Beta TSPs are returned, how does
the User know which ones to use?  Can they authenticate and get a
Service Catalog from any of them?

The _Federated Domain_ model addresses all these issues.  When
Keystones federate, they are really federating specific Domains.
Different domains can be used to manage different federated
environments for different purposes.  Federated Domains are also a
clean extension of the domain concept -- nothing changes on the client
side.

See the P2P Keystone blueprint for what is essentially the Federated
Domain model.

L.221

Federated Domains make the use of query parameters, such as
&includeAllSPs or &includeBETA completely unnecessary.

L.224

How does a Keystone know how to filter services that are returned to a
User?  The Federated Domain model addresses this using the existing
Endpoint Filtering capability.

L.230

Without using something like the Federated Domain model, how does BETA
know the scope of authentication that is possible for the given User?
What scope of authentication could the User know to request?

L.261

Imho, this is the most desireable approach; specifically the case
where the User "hits the service first".  This directly supports the
Federated Domain model.

L.273

The Circle of Trust (CoT) model is essentially the existing Proxy
Certificate model that is currently being used in operational grids.
This approach is already being implemented as part of the EGI
Federated Cloud project, since it can leverage the existing
operational Proxy Cert CAs.  Here's a recent paper describing this
work:
A´ . L. Garc´?a, E. F. del Castillo, and M. Puel. Identity Federation with
VOMS in Cloud Infrastructures. In IEEE CloudCom, 2013.

Before requesting any services, the User first does a
proxy_cert_request() to a trusted Proxy Cert CA.  This proxy cert is
then used for all service requests.  The SPs must all know and trust
the Proxy Cert CAs to validate proxy certs and enforce appropriate
policies.  This trust is established through the International Grid
Trust Federation (IGTF).  IETF RFC 3820 was produced to support this
approach:
[RFC3820] S. Tuecke, V. Welch, D. Engert, L. Pearlman, M. Thompson,
“Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) Proxy Certificate
Profile”, RFC 3820, June 2004.

L.287

The Federated Domain model requires that federating Keystones must
have the same "domain structure" for each domain being federated,
i.e., projects and roles.  Each local Keystone admin can give/revoke local
users project membership and assign them roles.  Each local Keystone
admin can also associate local service endpoints with projects, such
that endpoint filtering can be used.  To support things like Use Case
#4, I think roles will have to be domain-specific.  This is an obvious
impact on the data model.

Also, when creating a trust relationship (Figure 1), when adding a
Trusted SP or a Trusted IdP, they would have to be associated with a
Federated Domain.  That is to say, another call might be needed to
"Add a Federated Domain", i.e., its project and role definitions.
A Federated Domain is added first, and then TSPs and TIdPs could be
added/associated to one (or more) Federated Domains.

L.350

If the Federated Domain model is used, then information leakage should
be eliminated, since only the projects, roles and endpoints that are
specifically intended to be shared and exposed to federation users
ever will be.

L.443

Add P2P Keystones blueprint link.'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2014-06-27 05:16:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

L.260

How is domain/project mapping managed?  How does BETA know which
domain/project to map the user to?  Is this determined by the scope of
the token issued by ACME but only usable at BETA?  Will the
appropriate domain/project already exist at BETA, or will the
domain/project have to be created on-the-fly?

The User will be given some set of roles as part of the ACME
domain/project.  Will the BETA domain/project have these same roles?
If so, will they be understood to "mean the same thing"?  Will a role
mapping also be necessary between roles that have different names but
are known to be semantically equivalent in some manner?

This approach may be more scalable.  The Service Catalog received from
ACME only has the AUTH_URLS for the other TSPs in the federation,
rather than all services available to this User from all sites.  This
allows the User to lazily query other sites for available services.
However, this requires definite changes to the client.  The client
must be able to browse the available sites and keep track of multiple
tokens and services catalogs.  This is contrary to Item 3B (line 92)
-- if that requirement is chosen.

In the Federated Domain model, no changes on the client-side are
necessary, but at the cost of more complexity, and perhaps less
scalability, on the server-side.

In either case, there needs to be some common understanding between
ACME and BETA what the domain/project "means" that the User has
authenticated for.

This is another possibly off-the-wall thought: Could a "federated
domain definition" be carried in the token issued by ACME and then
presented to BETA?'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2014-06-29 16:08:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I have to say that I remain confused over the real advantages the additional complexity we are adding over and above pure federation.'}, {'account_id': 9959, 'date': '2014-06-29 18:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

I think the core issue is what constitutes "pure federation".
Clearly, only the simplest, essential calls should be added to the
API, but what those are depends on the scope of federation to be
supported and how much "federation machinery" is to be exposed to the
user, versus being managed "under the hood".  A real-time phone
discussion might be on order.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2014-06-29 21:04:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(2 comments)

responding to henry's comments"}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2014-06-29 21:15:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

responding to craig's comments:

1) It's managed through the mapping engine, I'm not sure I understand the first question.
BETA would establish a mapping through the OS-FEDERATION/mapping API.
If the user from ACME came to BETA with a scoped token, then it's proof he has role R on project P.
A sensible mapping on BETAs end would then give the user a token back with equivalent role R' to the equivalent project P'
Ideally the project P' on BETA would have to exist.

2) Yes, a role mapping would also be necessary.

3) I'm not sure about AUTH_URLs only in the extended SC, i'll think on that.

5) Agreed, I don't think we can get away from needed to map domains, projects and roles. As they will mean different things to different clouds.

6) What data would be in a "federated domain definition"?'}, {'account_id': 5956, 'date': '2014-06-29 21:45:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: -Code-Review

My feeling is that it would be best to split this change into two separate changes, since there are two different functionalities that can be implemented independently of each other. These are:

1) federated authentication between multiple keystones

2) determining the services that are available at multiple keystones.

It should be possible to implement 2) by doing a local un/pw login to your local keystone, and it should be possible to implement 1) without having the service of 2).

It might also speed up implementation as well as getting the changes agreed to'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2014-07-08 17:32:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

commit_message:
Federating multiple Keystones

This spec provides support for federating multiple Keystones.

bp keystone-to-keystone-federation

Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: Steve Martinelli <stevemar@ca.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: David Chadwick <d.w.chadwick@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: Kristy Siu <kwss@kent.ac.uk>

Change-Id: I648e6a9a18936c28c5104ae56c1127ac980be5e3

Enhance the validation of tosca

Enhance the validation of tosca with a parent constraint class
and different constraint sub-classes.

Implements: blueprint tosca-validation
