revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-25 14:15:09.000000000', 'message': "Add test for revoking a scoped v2 token

There was no test that showed what the server does when a scoped v2
token is revoked. The test shows that the behavior is incorrect and
the token isn't revoked.

Change-Id: I2a3443847b2699384413933ae164fdc183aa110f
"}, {'created': '2014-07-25 21:48:24.000000000', 'message': "Add a test for revoking a V2 token without validating first

There was no test that showed what the server did when a V2 token is
revoked and it hadn't been verified by a HEAD call. The test shows
that the server doesn't work correctly in this case and the token
remains valid.

Partial-Bug: #1348820

Change-Id: I2a3443847b2699384413933ae164fdc183aa110f
"}, {'created': '2014-07-25 22:09:36.000000000', 'message': 'Add tests related to V2 token issued_at time changing

There was no test that showed that when a V2 token is used in a V3
context its "issued_at" time changes. This affects validating a V2
token using V3 and also revoking a V2 token. The tests show the
current incorrect behavior.

Partial-Bug: #1348820

Change-Id: I2a3443847b2699384413933ae164fdc183aa110f
'}]
commit_message:
Add tests related to V2 token issued_at time changing

There was no test that showed that when a V2 token is used in a V3
context its "issued_at" time changes. This affects validating a V2
token using V3 and also revoking a V2 token. The tests show the
current incorrect behavior.

Partial-Bug: #1348820

Change-Id: I2a3443847b2699384413933ae164fdc183aa110f

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-23 20:22:52.000000000', 'message': 'Make return type from urlsplit private

The ModifiedSplitResult class should be private because when we drop
python 2.6 support we can replace the urlsplit() wrapper we have with a
reference to the one in the python standard library, which returns a
different type.

Change-Id: I413de125c58ee54a0aaaf608f57283e76283bf84
'}]
commit_message:
Make return type from urlsplit private

The ModifiedSplitResult class should be private because when we drop
python 2.6 support we can replace the urlsplit() wrapper we have with a
reference to the one in the python standard library, which returns a
different type.

Change-Id: I413de125c58ee54a0aaaf608f57283e76283bf84

commit_message:
Instance object coercion of bool to string is surprising

Fixes bug where assigning a bool value to a String field results in
coercion to the string that always evaluates to True in the boolean
context.

Closes-Bug: 1328387

commit_message:
Add "capabilities:" to multiple_backends extra-spec key

cinder-scheduler uses all the "capabilities:" to scope the
cinder-volume. With no "capabilities:" prefix set in extra_spec,
it will be no effect from cinder-scheduler to schedule the
cinder-volume, which is not the purpose of the testcase.
To address the review comment, This change will not remove but
adds 2 cases for the "capabilities:" prefix to volume type key:
extra-spec "capabilities:volume_backend_name".

Change-Id: Ie870091f2a5657b3ab6a0171de2cffe6945a0f7c
Closes-Bug: #1295050

commit_message:
Make logging more efficient in transport

Currently, transport does all the string format work on the request
and then it tries to log it without checking first if it is even
going to print.  This is low enough level code that it should be
more efficient.

Change-Id: I12ec7fe7488252c3b02c246179cdd7c1cf136716

commit_message:
Adds html result generator for tempest runs

* Adds "rally verify results --html --output-file output_to_html_file" flag to generate html result from
  tempest runs
* json2html generates html report similar to subunit2html using raw json
  from rally database
* Use mako templates for html generation

Change-Id: Ib390fa02aba4696bacaa4e4ec8b8c2481a54b0d2
Implements: blueprint tempest-subunit-to-json

commit_message:
Modify nova_network vlan provider

Set vlan_start option to be --vlan_start
instead of vlan

Change-Id: Ic65a6d5488938df5df544487dcfb8b29480645eb
Closes-bug: #1348664

commit_message:
Detect absence of 'use_ipv6' stanza in /etc/nova/nova.conf

- 'use_ipv6' configuration stanza is commented by default in
  /etc/nova/nova.conf.  We need to check return code of grep invocation
  to detect this.  If stanza is commented we consider IPv4.

Closes-bug: #1349432
Change-Id: I6311d02e4bb0ab9e62e5d82c12648cc509d67a9b

[{'created': '2014-07-09 16:35:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add the coverage-package-name argument to testr

Since our package name is different than the `name` in setup.cfg, this
option allows us to specify the real name to send to coverage. pbr 0.9
added this functionality, whereas before it was limited only to trying
to strip any leading "python-" from a name, which didn't work for us.

Change-Id: Id32752c6162bed602e1e4ea6c5d029af7002a31f
'}]
commit_message:
Add the coverage-package-name argument to testr

Since our package name is different than the `name` in setup.cfg, this
option allows us to specify the real name to send to coverage. pbr 0.9
added this functionality, whereas before it was limited only to trying
to strip any leading "python-" from a name, which didn't work for us.

Change-Id: Id32752c6162bed602e1e4ea6c5d029af7002a31f

commit_message:
Check firewall on slaves to detect security holes

In different deployment scenarios Puppet generates
different firewall rules and potentially can add
permit rule, which will allow access to unused or
secure ports/services. We should check iptables
for security holes on slaves:
 1. listen on admin interface on some unused port
    (tcp or udp);
 2. try to connect to that port from master node
    and send data;
 3. check that connection attempt was blocked and
    data was not received.

Change-Id: I1f625a75f4febf372948c47a1c920b6aed885a4b
Closes-bug: #1346265

commit_message:
Create snapshots if preparing of slaves fails

When some slave nodes do not bootstrap properly
while preparing slaves for further deployments
system test fails. In such cases tests should create
VMs snapshots to be able investigate why nodes
didn't boot over network.

Change-Id: Id6926637fe940dc29c0e5eb3e59a06f96e310363
Closes-bug: #1348249

commit_message:
Remove rst2script.sed and integration.sh

rst2script.sed was referenced in the Fedora getting started
documentation, but the recommended way to use Heat/Openstack
on Fedora is now to use RDO/packstack.

Also removes the reference to rst2script.sed in the
getting_started/on_fedora documentation.

Also removes obsolete integration.sh script.

Partial-Bug: 1338066

Change-Id: I7f2b0d84ccef324ccb8e32ca4c6d90f9a3f2dda3

commit_message:
libvirt: removing lxc specific disk mapping

Currently, LXC specific disk mapping is being created, preventing
the attached volumes from being added to the LXC disk mapping.
Removing this part, to allow volumes to be included in mapping.

Related-Bug: #1269990
Change-Id: I97bcff558b6d8876a10adb36c19ab3f4c972a708

[{'created': '2014-07-28 08:37:16.000000000', 'message': "Sync time on nodes before checking Ceph health

System test 'ceph_ha' almost always fails while
checking ceph health due to clock skew. That's
why an additional time synchronization and restart
of Ceph service was added to the test.

Change-Id: I4f493bf92a2ab28b4833cdcb46ed3a8a9a92fc0f
Closes-bug: #1336233

commit_message:
Sync time on nodes before checking Ceph health

System test 'ceph_ha' almost always fails while
checking ceph health due to clock skew. That's
why an additional time synchronization and restart
of Ceph service was added to the test.

Change-Id: I4f493bf92a2ab28b4833cdcb46ed3a8a9a92fc0f
Closes-bug: #1336233

commit_message:
Add parsing of hypervisor deployment tags

Patch include:
* Deployment tag qemu|kvm
  added in  the sanity.test_sanity_infastructure for
  tests: Check internet connectivity from a compute,
  Check DNS resolution on compute node. This give for us
  possibility not discover those tests in case if vcenter
  is set as hypervisor
* Add parsing of hypervisor
  date into fuel_plugin.ostf_adapter.mixin.py
* Add check for  libvrt_data
Change-Id: Idce25c31c0f001aa1a71fb790b912cddea6fb85b
Related: blueprint vcenter-hv-full-scale-support

commit_message:
Push the image cache ttl way up

There is no benefit to ever deleting images from the pxe cache except
when the cache is full. However the cache always consults the image
ttl, so as a short term measure, lets make the default far enough
apart that few use cases will result in it being deleted spuriously.

This patch sets the default image cache ttl to 1 week.

Change-Id: I97fec1336ab2a8aabf8cfd97534bda8d5dea1e85

What specific issue in stable branch are you trying to fix with that change? It looks more like a nice-to-have patch, so I doubt its right for backport.'}, {'account_id': 10114, 'date': '2014-07-27 17:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

HI Ihar,

We have seen issues with default http timeout (15 sec) values in some scenarios in our scale tests. There are two things we are doing to address this.

1. have configurability option as it may depend on the deployment use cases. This backport addresses this specific case.

2. Increase the default to 30 sec.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 10114, 'date': '2014-07-27 17:32:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10114, 'date': '2014-07-27 18:36:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Abandon this review?"}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2014-07-28 08:11:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, you should abandon that review with the wrong Change-Id.'}, {'account_id': 10114, 'date': '2014-07-28 14:51:55.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Corrected the ChangeId in the commit message (per Ihar's comment) .. But it generated a new review.. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/109872/

Hence abandoning this review."}]

commit_message:
Add configurable http_timeout parameter for Cisco N1K

http_timeout is a constant defined in the code. This change makes it
configurable by providing it as an option in the config file.

DocImpact

Conflicts:

        etc/neutron/plugins/cisco/cisco_plugins.ini
        neutron/plugins/cisco/common/config.py

Closes-Bug: #1332290 Change-Id: I429dd9efa43f6a596933359f4627a7761411e621
(cherry picked from commit a8d67485ab498a647b1f50184755c47b18e97e2c)

Change-Id: I9d602e9e4bcbd1d2957e186e1c33f6113e6f518e

commit_message:
Replace dict.iteritems() with six.iteritems(dict)

This change is needed to make Ceilometer code both Python 2.x and
3.x compatible in some future. Oslo modules are left without
changes in this change, that will be done directly in the
oslo-incubator code.

Partially-Implements: blueprint ceilometer-py33-support
Change-Id: Ic7fe5819f85524bb36f04dec6cad10d4cf2b935d

[{'created': '2014-07-17 15:18:51.000000000', 'message': 'Set promote_secondaries when creating namespaces

There is an sysconf entry controls the behaviour of deleting primary ip
(/proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/all/promote_secondaries). when set instead of
deleting the secondary address, it will be promoted to primary ip.

Without it, when init_l3 called on a port, it may unexpectedly delete
some useful ips.

Change-Id: I0b1b3bd6ade21129532c842daa31059ea164719e
Closes-bug: 1343320

is performed (/proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/all/promote_secondaries). when set

commit_message:
Set promote_secondaries when creating namespaces

there is a sysconf entry which controls how deletion of the primary ip
is performed (/proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/all/promote_secondaries). when set
instead of deleting the secondary addresses, one of them will be
promoted to primary ip.

Without it, when init_l3 called on a port, it may unexpectedly delete
some useful ips.

Change-Id: I0b1b3bd6ade21129532c842daa31059ea164719e
Closes-bug: 1343320

commit_message:
Make test_l3_agent._prepare_router_data a module function

Remove an unneeded class variable, allowing _prepare_router_data
to be changed to a module level function. This allows the function
to be reused by other tests cases.

Change-Id: Ia4de3c535c703fbb2528e6cc9594bcd34f50aca1

commit_message:
Add additional pipe for haproxy namespace

Allow haproxy to communicate with outside
world even if there is no vip present.

Also add restart action and fix meta-data

Change-Id: Ic3c561e603308029e2263fcd8a0afc8535addfdd
Closes-Bug: 1348181

commit_message:
Fix policy working process

Implement policy processing like in Keystone using protected()
method. It wraps API calls with role based access controls (RBAC).

Changes connected with host->computehost renaming were necessary to
unify work with policy manageable resources.

Implements blueprint: policy-fix-enforce
Change-Id: Ic6f6da868ef1fd2da37a08206cd16a013369cc63
Co-Authored-By: Nikolay Starodubtsev <nstarodubtsev@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Extension of DBDuplicateEntry exception

Added new field 'value' for DBDuplicateEntry exception.
It shows duplicated value for mysql and postresql 9.x engines
and is read from the error message using regular expressions.

The duplicated value can't be extracted from SQLite error messages,
so we do our best here for other db backends that we support.

Change-Id: I647e314cafe8ceb570bf18948d6ab83ab6afef97

Ian: thanks! I was confused at first when I saw this in my queue (I thought it looked familiar)... so this should fail to merge anyway right?'}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2014-07-15 09:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Ian, Marios, this is a confusing situation! What happened is that I934486b3ff5884063d29c6d9b66fd9b11140464c was applied to DIB. I based my first version of this patch on that. However it turned out that had an error in it, so it was reverted (I08a8feab541901c8fd0a803628f5aeb6c0eec598).

In response, I created a fixed version (Ibfb562c5970b40598fc95da1e8d4beb9d51d7612) which this patch now depends on.

I have also ported both these patches to dib-utils.'}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2014-07-15 09:03:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Jay, all credit to Ian Wienand for the spot. My patch is the dependent one.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2014-07-15 09:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Oh, i see!  sorry I was out on PTO last week, hence didn't notice the revert.  Looks like mine was missing a slash

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 8688, 'date': '2014-07-15 09:19:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For your interest, the root of the issue was that find returns the initial path in all results. EG `find .` => './a\n./b'. So I changed ^ to / in the regex and also removed the initial path from the `source ___` line."}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2014-07-17 07:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I see, thanks Alexis I was able to find the revert in the git log (fyi @ I08a8feab541901c8fd0a803628f5aeb6c0eec598 )'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2014-07-17 07:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Fix sourcing of environment files

Includes "Don't match editor backup files in environment" and "Order
execution of environment.d scripts". These had to be squashed because
the first change alone changes the order env.d scripts are sourced in.

The current glob match for environment files can source editor backup
files (foo.bash~) which will override the real changes you have made.
Other parts use the regex to avoid matching such files, so do
the same for environment file matching.  Note this has to match "."
unlike the other regex, as most env files are "foo.bash"

Also sort the files before sourcing them to ensure a reliable order.
This change should be in line with current expectations, given the
convention is to numerically prefix scripts in this directory.

Update of: I934486b3ff5884063d29c6d9b66fd9b11140464c
Subsumes: Icc509f695d7a15a8026d8c7e463f06acf65499d7
Change-Id: Ibfb562c5970b40598fc95da1e8d4beb9d51d7612

Fix typo in openstack-common.conf

cookiecutter inputs.

commit_message:
Unit tests for Mellanox deployment serializers

1. Added unit tests for Mellanox changes in deployment serializers.
2. Fixed conventions of python string formatting.

Closes-bug: #1343355

Change-Id: I33c7fd5b69b096de808cb8cabccaf6f6056f8508
Signed-off-by: Aviram Bar-Haim <aviramb@mellanox.com>

[{'created': '2014-07-28 08:50:37.000000000', 'message': "Replace iterator.next() with next(iterator)

Python 3 introduced a next() function to replace the next()
method on iterator objects. Rather than calling the method on the
iterator, the next() function is called with the iterable object
as it's sole parameter, which calls the underlying __next__() method.

As the next() function was backported to Python 2.6, we can
use it either in the 2.x or 3.x simultaneously - that's why
six.next() usage was also removed from the source code.

Partially-Implements: blueprint ceilometer-py33-support

commit_message:
Replace iterator.next() with next(iterator)

Python 3 introduced a next() function to replace the next()
method on iterator objects. Rather than calling the method on the
iterator, the next() function is called with the iterable object
as it's sole parameter, which calls the underlying __next__() method.

As the next() function was backported to Python 2.6, we can
use it either in the 2.x or 3.x simultaneously - that's why
six.next() usage was also removed from the source code.

Partially-Implements: blueprint ceilometer-py33-support
Change-Id: I47ad69b0e5dc0840f733230d485bb1443cff8e5b

commit_message:
Adding log messages to improve error handling

This patch adds log messages, where raised errors
do not propagate to user during resolve build in
function get_param.

Change-Id: Ie8c9b6377a2ac3424d76abe09529b9ad0c8a51f4
Closes-Bug: #1346968

commit_message:
Changed Mellanox drivers restart after iSER rename

Restart only mlx4_en module in case of iSER port renaming.
There is no need to restart mlx4_core for udev renaming.
No module has dependency in mlx4_en.

Closes-bug: #1346304

Change-Id: Ib9093dc3bdec46c2d95e32d2d300450e65abee41
Signed-off-by: Aviram Bar-Haim <aviramb@mellanox.com>

i don't understand why this is needed. OS_CONFIG_FILES is certainly not magic. It's discoverable via --help and well documented, more so than -m in fact.

i think i'd rather just see OS_CONFIG_FILES defined one time and exported from devtest_variables, that would be a clean up IMO and actually make os-apply-config quite a bit more useable manually from the command line when interacting with your devtest environment.

anyway, just my 2 cents, i'm not going to -1 on that account."}, {'account_id': 10373, 'date': '2014-06-30 16:33:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-30 16:33:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Clean-up os-apply-config lines in devtest.

Modify os-apply-config to use -m option instead of using
OS_CONFIG_FILES variable.

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-21 22:41:37.000000000', 'message': "Adds worker shell handler with dummied build

shell_nobuild.Handler is identical to shell.Handler except
the function build doesn't call deployer or truly build
an image, instead proceeding directly from unittest to
counting the assembly as READY.

Change-Id: I1ee70c3f1886901f2b70f74cf027f5d62fc5a24b
"}]
commit_message:
Adds worker shell handler with dummied build

shell_nobuild.Handler is identical to shell.Handler except
the function build doesn't call deployer or truly build
an image, instead proceeding directly from unittest to
counting the assembly as READY.

Change-Id: I1ee70c3f1886901f2b70f74cf027f5d62fc5a24b

commit_message:
Update ensure()/reconnect() to catch MessagingError

The error handling code that gets connections reset if necessary
caught ConnectionError. It really needs to catch MessagingError,
which ConnectionError inherits from. There are other types of
MessagingErrors that may occur, such as InternalError, and they need
to cause the connection to reset, as well.

This fix has already been merged into oslo.messaging.

--

Cherry-picked from oslo-incubator 234f64d608266f43d8856ff98c89ceba6699d752
See also https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1086077

Closes-bug: #1303890
Change-Id: Ibd93d083c0404afeb8a0f8d4cbde493255f0aa08

commit_message:
Fix the execution context

- the plan needs to be extended to include some field
  - heat template
  - heat parameters
  for now just move this to defaults
- make use of the mistral builtin action_context that
  holds the auth_token and project_id

Change-Id: I69e424d554ad46b8b2894f744c6963e104ad01c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-28 11:29:12.000000000', 'message': 'Properly render Neutron segmentation type and L23 provider

- previsous fix hided Neutron segmentation type (GRE, VLAN) when option
  "Neutron with GRE segmentation" or "Neutron with VLAN segmentation"
  was used.  So fix it display both L23 provider (OVS) and segmentation
  type (GRE or VLAN).  Now it appears "Neutron with OVS (VLAN
  segmentation)" or "Neutron with OVS (GRE segmentation)"
- NSX is a special case.  It segmentation type can by dynamically
  changed on Settings tab by changing NSX connector type (STT, GRE,
  Bridge, etc).  Just for now hide segmentation type for it, title on
  Networks tab would look like "Neutron with NSX"
- while here pull <span> out of if statement

Change-Id: I8b207e7b60d988884f151fefde600dea64976821
Closes-bug: #1347687
'}, {'created': '2014-07-28 11:50:07.000000000', 'message': 'Properly render Neutron segmentation type and L23 provider

- previsous fix hided Neutron segmentation type (GRE, VLAN) when option
  "Neutron with GRE segmentation" or "Neutron with VLAN segmentation"
  was used.  Return previous behaviour back.
- NSX is a special case.  It segmentation type can by dynamically
  changed on Settings tab by changing NSX connector type (STT, GRE,

  Networks tab would look like "Neutron with NSX", no matter what

- while here pull <span> out of if statement

commit_message:
Properly render Neutron segmentation type and L23 provider

- previsous fix hided Neutron segmentation type (GRE, VLAN) when option
  "Neutron with GRE segmentation" or "Neutron with VLAN segmentation"
  was used.  Return previous behaviour back.
- NSX is a special case.  It segmentation type can by dynamically
  changed on Settings tab by changing NSX connector type (STT, GRE,
  Bridge, etc).  Just for now hide segmentation type for it, title on
  Networks tab would look like "Neutron with NSX", no matter what
  connector type was chosen.
- while here pull <span> out of if statement

Change-Id: I8b207e7b60d988884f151fefde600dea64976821
Closes-bug: #1347687

commit_message:
Show help usage by default for fuelclient

Also added 'fuel help' as a useful option
(same as fuel -h) to show usage as well.

Change-Id: I79bb493ee5af46d166fc81d90beb3fa74ac348b6
Closes-Bug: #1348413

commit_message:
Set python hash seed to 0 in tox.ini

New tox (>=1.7.0) sets a random python hash seed by default. This is
generally good for testing because it will help keep projects working
regardless of the hash seed, but ceilometer unittests don't currently
pass with a random hash seed so set it to the python default seed.

This change will allow us to use new tox again and remove the
restriction on tox<=1.6.1 to run unittests.

Redundant setenvs for specific test envs are removed to prevent them
from overriding the PYTHONHASHSEED value.

Note this change will need to be backported to the stable branches to
keep unittests there working with new tox as well.

Change-Id: Ibc613d77ad52d5f7d8d613f3dd66ffba4117ff72

commit_message:
Add information about python2.6 into development documentation

- warning the user that Nailgun require python 2.6;
- give advice where user can found such python version.

Change-Id: I718f7d54bbee224215a26270f733d287f9720953
Closes-Bug: #1332330

commit_message:
Fixed stack never changed from DELETE_IN_PROGRESS

* Stack status is now set to ERROR, when a delete of instance fails
during stack delete operation

Change-Id: Ib86b3367a1c1546566deafe7a46bd153c4daa017
Closes-Bug: #1331916

Fixed method run_single_ostf_test

Need run only one OSTF test in this method to save our time.

Closes-Bug: #1348089

commit_message:
Cleanup and gate on hacking E711 and E712 rule

Fix the offending instances of the rule
and removes it from the ignore list in tox.ini
so that we can gate on E711 and E712 rules.
Most violations were in DB queries. Replace as follows:
  False -> sqlalchemy.sql.false()
  None  -> sqlalchemy.sql.null()
  True  -> sqlalchemy.sql.true()

This does same thing with Id84aa04697d1b3c23dc03195113e296c6715379d

Change-Id: Ia4e0a519cb8044364355bac5e138d833cc7b5d76

subject: Respect $TMP_DIR in more places
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-22 20:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-22 20:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-22 21:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-diskimage-builder-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-pep8/d4df806 : SUCCESS in 1m 08s
- gate-diskimage-builder-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python26/7c1f33d : SUCCESS in 47s
- gate-diskimage-builder-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python27/e3592e1 : SUCCESS in 59s
- check-tempest-dsvm-virtual-ironic http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-virtual-ironic/df986d4 : SUCCESS in 29m 03s'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-23 00:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures


- check-tripleo-novabm-undercloud-precise http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-novabm-undercloud-precise/3eb9783 : FAILURE in 44m 30s
- check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise/22f4331 : FAILURE in 45m 48s
- check-tripleo-novabm-overcloud-f20 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-novabm-overcloud-f20/9f01521 : SUCCESS in 1h 35m 53s'}, {'account_id': 10375, 'date': '2014-07-23 07:06:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2014-07-23 08:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I think you missed one in ./bin/dib-lint:62:TMPDIR=$(mktemp -d), otherwise lgtm'}, {'account_id': 12320, 'date': '2014-07-25 10:03:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Shouldn't those mktemp invocation just pass a parameter-less --tmpdir, so the default $TMPDIR (if set, /tmp otherwise) is used?
Usually $TMPDIR or $TMP are used to point to a directory for temporary files, $TMP_DIR seems like a third way for it."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:13:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Marios, dib-lint isn't run as part of a build, and $TMP_DIR isn't ever set in its context, so that's why I didn't update it."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Pino, $TMP_DIR is what we use as the build directory, defaulting to /tmp if not set. Not sure why it was preferred over $TMP or $TMPDIR, neither of which are set in my environment.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:50:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-diskimage-builder-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-pep8/6a21aca : SUCCESS in 37s
- gate-diskimage-builder-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python26/f45b397 : SUCCESS in 37s
- gate-diskimage-builder-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python27/86d282b : SUCCESS in 39s
- check-tempest-dsvm-virtual-ironic http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-virtual-ironic/1354f04 : SUCCESS in 25m 20s'}, {'account_id': 12320, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:54:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

James: I see nothing in d-i-b setting $TMP_DIR manually, so that's something you are setting externally prior to call diskimage-create. Hence, setting $TMP_DIR or $TMPDIR (and the latter is generally used) should not change much."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:57:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yes, $TMP_DIR is set externally.'}, {'account_id': 12320, 'date': '2014-07-25 13:59:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, `man mktemp` explicitly mentions TMPDIR being used with a parameter-less --tmpdir.

Actually, TMPDIR is even part of SUS, see http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/basedefs/V1_chap08.html#tag_08_03'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-25 15:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- check-tripleo-novabm-undercloud-precise-nonha http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-novabm-undercloud-precise-nonha/b12badd : SUCCESS in 56m 09s
- check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise-nonha http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-ironic-undercloud-precise-nonha/3a63d9f : SUCCESS in 52m 51s
- check-tripleo-novabm-overcloud-f20-nonha http://logs.openstack.org/34/108834/1/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-novabm-overcloud-f20-nonha/c53981b : SUCCESS in 1h 37m 39s'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2014-07-28 07:43:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

thanks for clarification James. I think what Pino is pointing out makes sense. Trouble is it looks like 'TMP_DIR' is used more often than 'TMPDIR' in the incubator scripts... though TMP_DIR is never set (no hits for 'TMP_DIR=').

I don't feel too strongly either way and don't know how much of a convention 'TMP_DIR' is vs the 'TMPDIR' default (at least for mktemp). I guess one point to be made here Pino is that the current form is better from a documentation point of view. If instead it looked like:


WORKING=$(mktemp) -d --tmpdir

then the reader would have to know that mktemp without 'tmpdir' param defaults to TMPDIR or /tmp - here is it explicit which variable you must set if you want to override."}, {'account_id': 12320, 'date': '2014-07-28 08:21:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Marios, I understand what you mean here. On the other side, I've always used for a decade TMPDIR, so e.g. `env TMPDIR=/special/path some-command` to give some command a special temporary directory.

I guess a compromise here could be the following: a) mktemp is used with parameter-less --tmpdir, so TMPDIR or /tmp is used, b) in diskimage-create TMPDIR is set as TMP_DIR if the latter is set too. This way, we can simplify elements in not having to spread the logic for choosing the temporary directory (so what mktemp does is just fine), and either a standard TMPDIR or the specific TMP_DIR can be used.

What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-28 10:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

TMP_DIR is the convention and accepted way to override /tmp in diskimage-builder currently.  Changing that is not the point of this patch. Certainly, if you feel strongly that it should be done another way, propose a patch to do that.'}, {'account_id': 12320, 'date': '2014-07-28 11:13:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you please point me at where I can read about this "convention", considering that most of the `mktemp -d` invocations I see at least in diskimage-builder and tripleo-image-elements do not use TMP_DIR at all?

Also, I don't see the point of doing a new patch after this one has been accepted, which would basically revert most of the changes done in this review request...'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-28 11:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

TMP_DIR is *already* used in diskimage-builder. grep the code.

even if that were to be changed, we would have to maintain backwards compatibility.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2014-07-28 12:07:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

pino made some good points and convinced me on irc to take a different approach that can honor TMPDIR as well for folks used to that convention. will work on a different patch for that.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-22 20:34:33.000000000', 'message': 'Respect $TMP_DIR in more places

$TMP_DIR was not always honored. For those folks with a tmpfs mounted in
/tmp, it was still possible to run out of space in /tmp.

Change-Id: I8b1a32795b1bcc323219f31e6ac062e181b213d0
'}]
commit_message:
Respect $TMP_DIR in more places

$TMP_DIR was not always honored. For those folks with a tmpfs mounted in
/tmp, it was still possible to run out of space in /tmp.

Change-Id: I8b1a32795b1bcc323219f31e6ac062e181b213d0

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 12634, 'date': '2014-07-28 09:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2014-07-28 09:34:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

[{'created': '2014-07-28 09:34:38.000000000', 'message': "Require Class['mysql::server'], not Service['mysqld'] when creating DB.

When using version >= 2.2 of the MySQL module, setting up
the database for Keystone depended on the MySQL service
(Service['mysqld']). However, if the service is not managed
by Puppet (e.g. it is managed through Pacemaker instead),
this would cause catalog compilation to fail because there
is no Service['mysqld']. This is the case when the MySQL
module is called with service_manage => false. Requiring
Class['mysql::server'] instead fixes this.

Change-Id: Ia1b34051dd6e4fc0916ac788d6027c1f987418a8
Closes-Bug: 1349316
"}]
commit_message:
Require Class['mysql::server'], not Service['mysqld'] when creating DB.

When using version >= 2.2 of the MySQL module, setting up
the database for Keystone depended on the MySQL service
(Service['mysqld']). However, if the service is not managed
by Puppet (e.g. it is managed through Pacemaker instead),
this would cause catalog compilation to fail because there
is no Service['mysqld']. This is the case when the MySQL
module is called with service_manage => false. Requiring
Class['mysql::server'] instead fixes this.

Change-Id: Ia1b34051dd6e4fc0916ac788d6027c1f987418a8
Closes-Bug: 1349316

commit_message:
Read template's expected value orchest test Part-2

In tests under /tempest/api/orchestration/, resources gets
created based on parameters defined in template (yaml, json).
But while verification of output, expected values are hard coded
in tests.
Expected values should be read from template only.
This patch covers the following files -
    test_environment.py
    test_nova_keypair_resources.py
    test_swift_resources.py

Closes-Bug: #1327919

Change-Id: Ie241b7f299487cd0db384778225823e96fecf440

[{'created': '2014-07-24 13:23:29.000000000', 'message': 'Pin python-swiftclient < 2.0.0

This requirement was introduced for Glance earlier [1]. This is not the
right way to pin versions, instead requirements repo should be used to
propagate version requirements to all projects.

Such incorrect pinning results in attempts to remove the pin during the
next requirements sync, as in [2].

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60224/
[2]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101753/

Change-Id: Iee194d7919d6e9c51aa9256e4c3a1421e9b79d3f
'}]
commit_message:
Pin python-swiftclient < 2.0.0

This requirement was introduced for Glance earlier [1]. This is not the
right way to pin versions, instead requirements repo should be used to
propagate version requirements to all projects.

Such incorrect pinning results in attempts to remove the pin during the
next requirements sync, as in [2].

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60224/
[2]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101753/

Change-Id: Iee194d7919d6e9c51aa9256e4c3a1421e9b79d3f

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-25 21:36:43.000000000', 'message': 'Remove wiki template

The wiki template has confused authors with regards to which
template they should use to author a new note.  Since the source
repository only contains notes in the "email" template format, we
should only contain that template here.  The wiki conversion can
be described on the OSSN process page instead.

Change-Id: I4a13ef98bcbcc8a49f14bf30096fb19b0afc8082
'}]
commit_message:
Remove wiki template

The wiki template has confused authors with regards to which
template they should use to author a new note.  Since the source
repository only contains notes in the "email" template format, we
should only contain that template here.  The wiki conversion can
be described on the OSSN process page instead.

Change-Id: I4a13ef98bcbcc8a49f14bf30096fb19b0afc8082

commit_message:
Enable the make_test_data.py in tools

Currently, the make_test_data.py is unavailable, because some related code
has been changed, this patch enable it.

Change-Id: Ia387c14241ebe52d6668e4af9f7616eb779f941e

refactoring is about making code cleaner and easier to extend.  it absolutely can include taking a tightly imperative system and expanding it out into a clean, declarative system. commit_message:
Add client response checking for data processing service

* Checks for response status codes to client side were added
* Checks for response status codes from all tests were removed

Partially implements: blueprint client-checks-success

Change-Id: Ib2a2632460aa39f5c7cfc66dbc601c5fa1a1baa5

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-25 14:49:39.000000000', 'message': 'Revert the conductor_workers to former default

During the refactoring of the conductor_workers parameter from nova::api
to nova::conductor, the conductor_workers default changed from
$::processorcount to the parameter being absent.

This patch reverts that change, so the refactoring does not introduce new
behaviour.

For reference see:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/106656
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108941

Change-Id: I908fc4953522f0b1db8f43882a44407aba9fa9f9
'}, {'created': '2014-07-25 16:38:44.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure conductor_workers stay at previous value

During the refactoring of the conductor_workers parameter from nova::api
to nova::conductor, the conductor_workers default changed from
$::processorcount to the parameter being absent.

While this is consistent with the nova default behaviour, it changes the
value for people who currently have a different default set. The solution is
to do nothing, in case no value is given.

For reference see:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/106656
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108941
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/list-of-compute-config-options.html

Change-Id: I908fc4953522f0b1db8f43882a44407aba9fa9f9
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure conductor_workers stay at previous value

During the refactoring of the conductor_workers parameter from nova::api
to nova::conductor, the conductor_workers default changed from
$::processorcount to the parameter being absent.

While this is consistent with the nova default behaviour, it changes the
value for people who currently have a different default set. The solution is
to do nothing, in case no value is given.

For reference see:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/106656
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108941
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/list-of-compute-config-options.html

Change-Id: I908fc4953522f0b1db8f43882a44407aba9fa9f9

Refactored System tests for Murano and Sahara

Fixed some issues with names, mixed string patterns,
lines length and etc.

commit_message:
Refactor functional tests

* Reduce amount of time waiting for element that doesn't exist
* Improve some xpaths
* Fix screenshot taking to happen only on fail
* Add config file to .gitignore
* Testcase for checking integer field was removed since
  it checks library code, not Murano
* Generates test package archive with different fqns
* Use muranoclient insted of request module
* Maximaze browser window before test execution
* Use consts.py instead of common.ini to keep xpaths

After this patch app-incubator is not needed for test run

Closes-Bug: #1343210
Change-Id: Ied6390b5aed6421182a2f2e3a825e079cfef4591

subject: Add resize-server for nova benchmark

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 12484, 'date': '2014-07-28 06:50:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2014-07-28 06:50:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2014-07-28 07:00:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Thank you for a patch it looks good. But could you add functional testing for it as well.

commit_message:
Adds "user-password-update" to v3/test_users

This submission is to verify user-password-update functionality
and also added required support functions in both XML/JSON
interfaces.

Change-Id: Ifcac99095fb4e07ccaa2b6f87ac836c3959ef37a

Remove sqla_07 from tox.ini

Remove support of sqla_07 test according to global requirements

commit_message:
Periodic runner refactoring

  'preiodic' runner renamed to rps (runs per second).
  Extensible pool of multiprocessing.Process was implemented instead
  of using constant length multiprocessing.Pool. That should decrease memory
  usage on large iterations and related errors.

Change-Id: I6e367ea30d89d5d0e7ba212ed22e8658421ac9bd

commit_message:
Adds description of leastrouter option

Describes the router assignment behaviour of the LeastRoutersScheduler
option.

Change-Id: I8327e865d07f224575d095036212ffdd5f06fcfc
Closes-Bug: 1325458

commit_message:
Override configure_logging to quieten iso8601 and requests

This prevents the following messy output:

 Starting new HTTP connection (1): localhost

Change-Id: Ibb80f792939441dc90c4a041ae83f38b0c7e3ec2

commit_message:
Data Processing: Adding keypair import from launch cluster dialog

Added the ability to import keypair from launch cluster dialog.
This brings the launch cluster functionality more in-line with
the launch instance functionality.

Change-Id: I35d1154713974609120df66d1f3f141c3f25b488
Closes-Bug:  bug #1336297
Co-Authored-By: Andrew Lazarev <alazarev@mirantis.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-07-10 18:06:45.000000000', 'message': 'Add psmisc package to ironic-conductor

A recent change to Ironic (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/90126/) introduces
a dependency on the fuser utility which is provided by the psmisc package.
This adds it to the package dependencies of ironic-conductor in case it is not
included in the base distro install.

Change-Id: I4dbc4a661962aa496194f2e8bae0d330af1444bd
'}]
commit_message:
Add psmisc package to ironic-conductor

A recent change to Ironic (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/90126/) introduces
a dependency on the fuser utility which is provided by the psmisc package.
This adds it to the package dependencies of ironic-conductor in case it is not
included in the base distro install.

Change-Id: I4dbc4a661962aa496194f2e8bae0d330af1444bd

'}, {'created': '2014-07-23 11:42:50.000000000', 'message': 'Add psmisc package to ironic install

psmisc provides fuser which is required by ironic. On Ubuntu this 
is installed by default and in CI the ci-tools element 79-te-worker

commit_message:
Add psmisc package to ironic install

psmisc provides fuser which is required by ironic. On Ubuntu this 
is installed by default and in CI the ci-tools element 79-te-worker 
installs it. However some Linux distros do not install this package 
by default.

Change-Id: I72051a3134ec4b46402b1d5a0f3dab9e70064866
NB: name is psmisc across Debian, Ubuntu, RHEL + SUSE.

commit_message:
Allow tox tests with complex OS_TEST_DBAPI_CONNECTION URLs

In particular, this allows OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION URLs with
alternate drivers like mysql+mysqlconnector://... to survive through
into OS_TEST_DBAPI_CONNECTION for the actual unittest.

Change-Id: I712d9366e616a551f4b2bd225de42469a35b363f

commit_message:
Refactoring Glance logging lowering levels

This change fixes translations to be using correct translation functions.
Contains few log level drops for too high logging levels.

This PS does not address logging changes for modules under glance/store/
due to the new repo request. After stores are moved to their own repo
new PS will be submitted for those.

This PS does not touch the test code.

Separate PS will be submitted for log lever raises withing codebase
as requested during the spec review.

Related to bp refactoring-glance-logging

Change-Id: I683c35face8d5b7056ef7fedcd75deb63dbbf8e2

commit_message:
labs: make Ubuntu 14.04 LTS default

This patch makes Ubuntu 14.04 LTS the default for osbash
basedisks.

Implements: blueprint openstack-training-labs
Change-Id: I76e7f5f47d5f68a1513ac9136902c28fbe173fe8

This patch adds an osbash support library for Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.

It allows osbash to build basedisks based on that distribution.

The patch also documents the new option in localrc.

Note that the new library differs from the Ubuntu 12.04 LTS version only
in the URL of the ISO image. The URL could be passed as an argument and
both libraries merged. Such a refactoring can be undertaken later on,
should we keep adding libraries we almost identical content.

Also note that these libraries do not pass bashate (formerly know as
bash8). Maybe we can find a better way to store the boot argument string
that is bashate conformant, readable/editable, and correct code.

commit_message:
labs: add Ubuntu 14.04 LTS support library

This patch adds an osbash support library for Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.

It allows osbash to build basedisks based on that distribution.

The patch also documents the new option in localrc.

Note that the new library differs from the Ubuntu 12.04 LTS version only
in the URL of the ISO image. The URL could be passed as an argument and
both libraries merged. Such a refactoring can be undertaken later on,
should we keep adding libraries we almost identical content.

Also note that these libraries do not pass bashate (formerly know as
bash8). Maybe we can find a better way to store the boot argument string
that is bashate conformant, readable/editable, and correct code.

Implements: blueprint openstack-training-labs
Change-Id: I2a6f848f47e8bcb5a9ff7bb3abb5cbef9d7790a5

subject: A resolution on standards of behavior during elections
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 964, 'name': 'Anne Gentle', 'email': 'annegentle@justwriteclick.com', 'username': 'annegentle'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1779, 'name': 'Daniel Berrange', 'email': 'berrange@redhat.com', 'username': 'berrange'}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}, {'_account_id': 2889, 'name': 'Aeva Black', 'email': 'aeva.online@gmail.com', 'username': 'tenbrae'}, {'_account_id': 6316, 'name': 'Anita Kuno', 'email': 'anteaya@anteaya.info', 'username': 'anteaya'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}]

[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:15:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/45/100445/1/check/noop/37fe51c : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:28:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

See also Anita's original draft: I00d342e6a871c3500613097c2e3fc3a502b03ddd"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:33:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I like this approach

I'd much rather an online form where candidates and the community as a whole can pledge to adhere to the code of conduct, but that would need someone to volunteer to set it up. Maybe a simple wiki page with a list of the names of those who have pledged?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

FYI this is intended as a light-weight counter-point to the original idea of a more strictly enforced approach:

  https://review.openstack.org/98675

The motivation is simply to push the debate forward, as opposed to supplanting the prior proposal.

Thanks,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:39:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@markmc: sure, I'd be open to changing to an online pledge, if we're confident that the mechanics of this can be set-up in a fairly lightweight way without putting too much of a burden on the election officials.

I guess the attraction of ML approach is the more direct non-repudiation aspect of an individual email, as opposed digging through the revision history of an individual wiki page to check who has added who's name and when.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2014-06-17 10:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think an additional form is redundant in the face of existing commitments made to the community code of conduct when joining the foundation.

What the email does is provide a venue where an individual can assert, in "public", their commitment to that code. Writing that commitment down is a valuable part of nomination that, for the individual doing the writing, is a good deal more meaningful than clicking on a form. What we want is for individual to be saying "I'm going to be good" not clicking through something that looks and feels like an EULA .

Evaluating the public assertion can be an important part of the election process: Can this person convince me they are good folk?'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-06-17 10:50:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like the idea of including the prolog in their email as opposed to just clicking approval on an online form.

I feel that online agreement tickboxes have been de-valued by corporations/organizations which force people to tick-agree to online Ts&Cs, to the extent that people don't really believe anyone reads (or cares about) these online agreements anymore before agreeing to them.

Having candidates adding the suggested prologue to their email is a more credible / proactive action for them to take."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-17 11:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I like the declaration. There is something different about someone reading, writing, and sending it out under their name than a checkbox.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-17 11:30:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2014-06-17 13:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like this idea, it is simple and lightweight.

I have one question though - if there was a case where someone saw what they thought was not in the ethos of OpenStack, would they just post an email to the -dev list? (not saying that is wrong, just wondering how the community can see reports, to evaluate them)

One (not major) inline suggestion.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-17 13:44:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> I have one question though - if there was a case where someone saw what they thought was not in the ethos of OpenStack, would they just post an email to the -dev list?

Yep, exactly, that was the thought.

If an unsolicited private email lands in Alice's inbox and she find it merely irritating, she can use her judgement to silently move it to here spam folder ...

Whereas if Bob receives the same email, and he finds it truly objectionable, he would be encouraged to draft a quick email to the os-dev list reporting the incident.

Either way, Alice, Bob and the rest of the community get to exercise their judgement in terms of withholding their votes from the relevant candidate, or not.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2014-06-17 14:03:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Thanks for the clarification - that's what I thought, but I wanted to make sure I was reading it right."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2014-06-17 16:57:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I prefer Anita's original approach.  At its core, I believe hers is merely a statement of the community's values.  I think the concern about the procedural aspects of it is warranted, but I believe that can be addressed.  I would like to see the process minimized and rely on existing Foundation CoC processes wherever possible.

This approach actually seems more process oriented, with required email footers, signup forms, pledge pages, etc.  I don't think any of that is necessary, and will just end up adding red-tape to candidacies.  The _important_ thing is that we establish what our expectations are and communicate them.  We don't need to do that by attaching boilerplate to everyone's emails.

Finally, we've seen one recent instance where we felt like our expectations for election behavior may not have been met.  That was by a non-candidate actor.  I think that this focus on candidates signing pledges does not effect what I think is the optimal solution: communication of our expectations to everyone.  It might even have the opposite effect of suggesting that candidates (those who have signed the pledge) are the only ones subject to such restrictions.  (I realize there is a footnote about supporters signing such pledges, but that is clearly a very optional expectation, and I'm not sure hundreds of messages to the dev list saying "I support Alice and I pledge to ..." are useful.)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2014-06-17 17:24:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

One of the main reasons that I liked this suggestion was the removal of the TC from governing their own elections.

From a long term governance perspective this is much more optimal - I realise that this is not an issue right now (and am in no way casting any dispersions on any TC member, past or present), but just looking towards the future.

The TC is an elected, executive body, and as such the elections should be governed and regulated by a third party.

This solution allowed for that, but if we can find a way of combining that aspect of this proposal, and the reduction of red tape in I00d342e6a871c3500613097c2e3fc3a502b03ddd that would be great.

@James - 

> It might even have the opposite effect of suggesting that candidates (those who have signed the pledge) are the only ones subject to such restrictions

It is not unheard of for candidates to held responsible for the actions of their campaign teams - would you see that fitting in the OpenStack community?'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-17 17:50:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@jeblair

Your feedback is most welcome.

While I hear your concerns about weighing down elections with additional process, to be fair this approach doesn't require *all* of the "email footers, signup forms, pledge pages" are applied ... rather only *one* of those option is required.

Also, I would argue that the cost of a little extra process for everyone involved in an election (that already involves a little bit of process anyway) is potentially way less than the fall-out from a single case of an investigation/termination that turns ugly.

> The _important_ thing is that we establish what our expectations are and communicate them

Agreed.

My proposal is more oriented towards the bankend of the process (i.e. what to do when expectations aren't met) as opposed to the frontend (communicating those expectations).

> Finally, we've seen one recent instance where we felt like our expectations for election behavior may not have been met. That was by a non-candidate actor.

Exactly.

So if that were to happen again, my aim would be to get it out into the open quickly and apply the disinfectant property of good ol' sunlight. The community would likely "punish" the candidate in their own direct way, i.e. at the ballot box.

If OTOH the community fails to react by withholding their votes, then I guess the values being promoted aren't really reflecting the *actual* values of the community.

But I trust that they are, so would have confidence that the "right" outcome would ensue. 

If we perform the same Gedankenexperiment with the strict-enforcement model, I'd fear that one of the following unhappy outcomes may ensue:

* the process is under-specified to the extent that it's found to be unworkable in practice
* the process is challenged, becomes bogged down in legal argument and goes nowhere
* the process is applied rigorously and a stiff penalty of termination of membership is handed down to the non-candidate actor *only*, some time after the election result has been declared (so that the original winner retains their seat)
* the election is stopped in its tracks multiple times on report and counter-report, chaos ensues

> It might even have the opposite effect of suggesting that candidates (those who have signed the pledge) are the only ones subject to such restrictions.

Yes, short of us re-inventing a complex regulatory edifice to spell out all the rules that apply in every situation, IMO there is always going to be some residual perception that candidates are the focus of oversight (as opposed to campaigners/supporters etc.)

In any case, I thank you for your thoughtful feedback!

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2014-06-19 11:34:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm with James on that one...

(1) I think it's sufficient for the election official, in the email asking for self-nominations of candidates, to remind everyone of the rules and the ties to the Code of Conduct. Candidate pledges can't hurt, but supporters pledge sounds like a noise of overkill noise for our ML.

(2) Since campaigning happens at the same time as votes (and you can't change your vote after having voted), Bob's email may happen too late for most voters to act on it. We want a process that let us look into issues even after the vote is concluded.

(3) I also like that there is a clear abuse report process. I expect we have a lot of Alices in our community that would prefer not to call out someone on a public ML but would feel comfortable reporting what they consider inappropriate behavior to a third-party using a determined abuse report process.

Basically I think we already have a system in place (the Community Code of Conduct) to encourage good behavior around elections. We just need to stress that the CoC applies to campaigning, give clearer examples, and remind everyone of those principles when election period starts. I think Anita's version is closer to that spirit and actually does not invent a whole new process (which IMHO make the ties to the CoC less visible)."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-06-19 11:57:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Has our CoC ever been unit tested? Have there been reported events that the Foundation has dealt with?

I remain pretty uncomfortable assuming the answer is yes until I know. Because between what happened this last time, and in the initial foundation election where Shanely got driven off (and the details remain murky), it's not clear to me that that path is working. I'd love to know of counter examples.

I think that's where I see this differently, in that involving foundation staff for abuse reports is the process heavy path with a lot of unknowns, and the community pledge from a candidate is the process light path."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2014-06-19 12:40:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I also don't buy that the Foundation is necessarily the body immediately responsible for enforcing any code of conduct within our community

I see the technical community as being responsible for its own culture and the conduct of its own community, with perhaps the Foundation as a body of last resort"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2014-06-19 14:55:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Actually the Shanely case is a good counter-example: the concern was (kind of) aired publicly rather than reported through more.. official channels, but I wouldn't classify the whole experience as perfect. I think relying on public shaming has its limits too.

Mind you, the two proposals are not exclusive at all. It's a fact that the CCoC covers elections and the process to report violations to it is built in the bylaws already. It's a fact that you are always free to use public shaming when exposed to questionable behavior. That's why I think the key is to further define questionable behavior, rather than encourage a particular way to fix issues. Both options will be available anyway."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:11:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

TBH I don't think the Shanley Kane incident is really relevant here as:

* she didn't end up actually running for election (so sympathetic voters couldn't reward her for doing so)
* the person who sent the offensive email was never widely identified (so avenging voters couldn't punish them at the ballot box)
* the election involved was for the board of directors, so wouldn't even fall under this policy in any case"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-20 08:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-20 08:21:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Starting check jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-20 08:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/45/100445/2/check/noop/1112111 : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-20 08:25:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The latest version of the patchset lightens the process load by not requiring emails from supporters, rather an expectation of their good behavior is expressed by the candidate themselves.

So the concern expressed about a storm of ML noise is now met, as no additional mails are needed (instead the affirmation is only added to nomination mails that would otherwise have been sent anyway).

Another concern was expressed about the edge case where bad behavior only comes to light *after* many voters have actually voted. I actually referred to that eventuality in my ML thread, thusly:

 "If someone has already cast their vote when the report of some
  questionable behavior surfaces, well so be it. The electorate
  has a long memory and most successful candidates end up running
  again for subsequent elections (e.g. a follow-on term as PTL,
  or for the TC)."

So the idea is that the electoral "punishment" is simply deferred to another day.

Finally, some reference has been made to events in the recent PTL elections. I would encourage reviewers to war-game out some potential outcomes of the soft-enforcement and strict-enforcement models, had each been applied in that case.

Here's one way that the Foundation-enforcement model *may* have played out, for example:

* the gravity of the offences would not have been considered sufficient for terminiation of membership, so the Foundation is left in a quandary as to how to apply some lesser penalty 
* some sort of edict or "motion of censure" is drafted 
* the Foundation Secretary publishes that edict
* the community is left scratching their heads in confusion (reminder: even the TC didn't know who the secretary was when this process was recently discussed, so it's quite unlikely they would be known to a typical ATC)

Just some further food for thought ...

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-06-20 12:19:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

++ nice job on this, Jim, thx!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2014-06-20 17:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2014-06-23 16:26:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I was not working on OpenStack during July/August 2012, so this set of comments is the first I have encountered discussion of events that took place during that time.

So far I have learned about the information in this article (note the article begins with an ad - click the top right corner link to move to the article - and contains some broken links): http://www.itworld.com/cloud-computing/287805/openstack-allegation-abusive-conversation-under-investigation

As well as the contents of this post, made August 6 2012 to the Foundation mailing list: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/foundation/2012-August/001059.html
Note the identification that independent legal counsel was made available to both parties affected in this situation, both parties co-operated with independent legal counsel and the outcome was that neither party wanted to continue to pursue the matter. Also note that an email address was provided for the use by anyone who had any further questions or concerns about the matter.

Based on the facts I have collected so far, I am finding that an independent process was undertaken, which included both affected parties and the decision of the parties to not pursue the matter was honoured.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-23 16:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Verified

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2014-06-24 21:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Ok, some elements that could be part of this


Election official receives complain, gathers information and brings it to the subset of the TC who still have a mandate

That group can work with the election official to talk to all of the parties affected, reprimand people, gather apologies, figure out whether the election may have been undermined, etc.

That group can advise the election official to re-run an election

That group works with the election official to publish an official summary of the incident, preferably with names  and other identifying details redacted. The group could choose to name names if it felt it was necessary, however. The summary would include any apologies given, etc.

The main purpose of the official summary would be to educate the entire community about our culture and values, not to punish those involved

The ED/Foundation CoC process would be the last resort the group would reach for, in a case where the technical community feels the issue is sufficiently extreme that removal of Foundation membership might be warranted'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2014-06-24 21:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The purpose of all of that is to avoid immediate public shaming or Foundation intervention, but still allow for positive lesson-learning and culture-building'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2014-06-24 21:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
A resolution on standards of behavior during elections

Adds a resolution on a "soft-enforcement" model for maintaining
high standards of candidate behavior during election periods.

Change-Id: Ie5efe9e520aca8cd375dd1caf8f895163477316a

subject: Adds a resolution addressing expected election behaviour

Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2014-06-10 14:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

A few thoughts:

1. This responsibility should not rest with the TC, as 1/2 may be seeking re-election at that point in time. (Electoral Commissions / Election Committees are formed just for this reason - we use to make resignation from the electoral commission a condition of running in elections)
The body that adjudicates these elections should be totally independent.

2. The process of formal hearings needs to be defined (i.e. should be done in public (where possible), and formal findings should be published by whatever group does the investigation. This should include the ability for the accused to present counter evidence / a defence.

3. A path of appeal needs to be defined.

4. The rules need to be clearly defined and numbered, so there is no confusion of what someone is accused of (i.e. the investigating group can release a statement the "Candidate X has been accused of breaching rule X.Y")

I am not sure about how you enforce penalties - maybe the election groups / the TC could write to the board?

Removing a member is the nuclear option though - there should be some staged levels of penalties, but that would most likely require a change to the by-laws.'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2014-06-11 13:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

I think the commentary so far fails to take into account the amount of time in which this kind of process can take place.

Given that the elections, their duration, order and time they must take place are governed by the tc charter, any investigation of abuse and findings has about a 24-48 hour window. If a candidate is removed, the poll must be stopped, the electorate informed, another poll must be started (given there are at least 2 eligible candidates) and the poll must be open for 7 days. The plt election polls must be concluded before the tc nomination period is over - optimally I would like to see plt elections completed with at least 3 days remaining for tc nominations to be fair to prospective candidates.

Every disruption to our electoral system shakes community trust in our system. If anything threatens the integrity of our system it needs to be addressed swiftly so that the process can continue, retaining the faith of the electorate, and the business of the ptls and tc members can continue. This is my primary objective.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2014-06-11 23:09:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

Anita- Thanks for drafting this.  Comments/suggestions inline.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2014-06-12 08:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2014-06-13 11:10:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)

Sorry if I was too forceful with my comments - I only meant to suggest things.

This is an area that I have a lot of experience with, and feel quite strongly about, so that is why I may have come across too insistent.

I am looking at this from a worst case scenario.

One of the penalties suggested has massive consequences. 

If you remove someone from the foundation, and if that persons job is to work on OpenStack, they will not longer be able to work. (Membership is required to contribute) [1]

Bearing in mind the consequences, the rules should allow for Due Process, and assumption of innocence.

I wasn't aware that this was a draft, I thought it was a final (ready to be voted on) resolution. I tried to engage with this topic on the mailing list, but the conversation seemed to die out.

I will wait until there is another draft before commenting again.

1 - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/How_To_Contribute#Contributor_License_Agreement"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2014-06-13 12:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I think this draft successfully captures the intent, but goes a bit too far in the consequence of violation. In particular we don't have the power to directly terminate anyone's membership for violation of the Code of Conduct.

IMHO everything is fine up to line 28. The TC chair will communicate the issue to the rest of the Technical Committee, which may collectively decide to report the issue to the Board of Directors, which may or may not take action regarding the Foundation individual membership status.

In particular, the election officials, or the TC, do not decide what constitutes a violation of the Community Code of Conduct: the board does. And violations of the Code of Conduct are not clearly grounds for termination of membership status -- nothing in the bylaws says so. Bylaws only say that "Members shall comply with the Community Code of Conduct", without detailing the consequences or the process followed in case of violation. So any action would take a specific resolution from them.

I would also add that while collecting the evidence, the election officials and/or the TC shall of course hear the accused party so that they can defend themselves. The current draft is a bit too slanted towards accusation and never ever mentions defense.'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2014-06-13 13:04:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

Thank you for commenting, Thierry.

"I think this draft successfully captures the intent, but goes a bit too far in the consequence of violation. In particular we don't have the power to directly terminate anyone's membership for violation of the Code of Conduct."
Great, thank you for that feedback. Yes as far as the consequences of violation I had merely taken what had been said in the original tc meeting and pasted it in: 20:48:06 <jeblair> i believe CoC violations are grounds for termination of membership status which means no voting or running in elections http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc/2014/tc.2014-06-03-20.03.log.html

Since you, Monty, Mark McLoughlin and Jim (and Jeremy, though he isn't on the tc) know far more about the bylaws and what process we already have, I had meant this as a placeholder for more and better commentary to build this out a bit. Since the process of delivering a decision and undertaking any process, whatever it is lies with the tc, I was hoping this would be a space to hear from the tc. Now Jim has been away for a week and a half and I have been caught totally unprepared for the sinister motivations I am accused of having for being weak in this area, but I do hope we can clear a space where we can have a conversation about consequences and I am happy to write them up once I have some.

"IMHO everything is fine up to line 28. The TC chair will communicate the issue to the rest of the Technical Committee, which may collectively decide to report the issue to the Board of Directors, which may or may not take action regarding the Foundation individual membership status." I can offer a new patchset with this edit. Thanks Thierry.

"I would also add that while collecting the evidence, the election officials and/or the TC shall of course hear the accused party so that they can defend themselves. The current draft is a bit too slanted towards accusation and never ever mentions defense." That is true. As a first draft I put together the information I was most confident in. I was uncertain how we wanted to handle the defense (I don't even think that is the correct word) hmmmm, explanation, comments, rebuttal, statement... I still don't think I have it yet, but anyway I wasn't sure how we wanted to handle it so I didnt' include any wording around it since I had none.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-13 13:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Eoghan linked to this inline in ps6, but it's easy for it to get lost there, so ...

See also http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-June/037766.html

With proposals like this it can sometimes work out well for several people to take a stab at drafting something like this rather than attempting to nitpick the first draft towards a conensus

e.g. if Eoghan drafted an alternative policy with the tone he's aiming for, we might decide we like elements of both ..."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:10:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

But obviously needs to be finished...'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: -Verified

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-17 08:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified+1
